Early Access Review
								FIRST OF ALL NOTE THAT THIS GAME IS ON EARLY ACCESS (PRE-ALPHA), MEANING ITS NOT A FULLY DEVELOPED GAME WITH NO BUGS AND ALL CONTENT AVAILABLE.I played the original dundef and i liked dd2 just as much.Keeping true to the original game, still blending the fun of tower-defense game with action rpg games, this sequel is just as fun, if not MORE fun than the original dundef. (And it's only on early access! Imagine when it's fully released!)~PROS~-Better Graphics (LMFAO wHo cAREAS Xd seriously.)-Characters are more customizable with the new accessory patch!-The new sphere skill tree is better than dd1's skill point system imo. + UBER SPEC !!! (game-changing spec for each classes towers.)-4 HERO ABILITIES COMPARED TO DD1'S 2 HERO ABILITY.-The world is more interactive (Pre-Set Traps!)-Class COMBOES! water + electric = electrocute? oil + fire = ignite? yes please!~CONS~-The towers are BOOORING. I miss the bowling ball turret from DD1 T_T-BUGS GLITCH BUGS GLITCH (But it's okay, since its only Pre-Alpha.-NEED MORE HEROES!-Some Spec is just utter 5H!T AND USELESS. MORE CHARACTER SPEC PLZ!!!-â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ AI GETS STUCK AND IT PISSES ME OFF! (Could be exploited too, but what fun would that be?)Overall, the game's progess is looking REAAAAL good. I was skeptical about buying it first, but then Trendy really showed me their hard work on making this game, even convincing me to buy the collector's edition (DAMMIT TRENDY!)9/10. HIGHLY RECOMMEND PLAYING THIS WITH YOUR FRIENDS! Soloing is possible, but it gets BOOORING REAL FAST, but if you play this game with your friends (4 stack if possible) it is just simply AMAZING.<3 u Trendy, keep up the good work!-Popon

content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								I really wanted this game to do well. I have to just stop playing this game. Every time I come back to it every mechanic changes and progression is flipped around and left incoherent. The developers seem to not know what they want to do and I just cant support this any more.  As of right now. The game does have entertaining aspects to it. Classes feel fun, buildings are entertaining and flashy. But the bad things like certain monster forcing play styles is just jarring and not needed. Goblin tank forces you into tanking because it just plows through any tower without stopping and requires massive amounts of dps to kill it. They added the annoying talent system from Diablo 3. Want to find tune some thing? Too bad you have to gain 4 levels to add one point to the thing you want.  I suggest Coop if you are interested in the game. After hitting about level 45-50 it gives you an enormous gear check and soloing comes to a grind.Best of luck Trendy. I loved Dungeon Defenders 1. I dont know what went wrong in house, but this doesnt feel like a sequel. Feels like some thing EA would do to an IP they want to get rid of. Ill check in again once you guys officially release this game.

								I'd be able to recommend this game easily before this recent update. This update not only made most farming before it worthless, but it made the game bland and linear. The new ascension system is sad and uninspired and the new inventory system is terrible. The UI got much worse (though it wasn't anything great before it's worse now) and they replaced spheres with terribly implemented "shards" with WoW like inspiration. In that they're much less worth investing time in, much like the rest of the game now. It's become just as unfun and unrewarding as other tower defense games, if it isn't worse than them. Truly the "endgame" update... 2/109/10 pre update.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
Early Access Review
								I've logged into this game every so often since they very first released it as a paid beta. Coincidentally, each time I see what they've done in the latest update, the pulsating cancer in myâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥grows slighly larger. Somehow the devs have managed to make an even bigger and more unethical cash grab than the first game, which was produced under Chinese sweatshop conditions. But at least that one was fun.Originally, a lot less emphasis was placed on the microtransactions, but now the game is essentially another â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ Korean MMO grindfest with state of the art psychological exploitation. Every nasty business model around has been distilled and injected into this game which plays you much more than you play it. There is very little strategy in the shockingly limited towers and abilities you possess, and every inch of the game has recieved the 'competitive' sterilization that never fails to suck all the fun out of multiplayer titles. You can also find more impactful character customization in a Kim Kardashian dress up game. No matter how much I try to push a single stat, my max level character feels like it plays exactly the same as it did at level 1. Also, you're forced by both level design and game mechanics to use both towers and abilities, because Trendy sees their players as vegetables who shouldn't be deciding anything for themselves. I would have quit this much, much earlier if I didn't like DD1 so much, but I guess it's what I get for hoping a F2P game will be good. Loot is boring, pets are boring, the game is boring, the art is pretty nice, the cancer hurts, and I regret spending $30 and however much time on this game. I could see myself recommending this game to devoted fans of cookie clicker and/or lobotomy patients.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								-This review may get some future edits-Apparently there is few bad reviews for this game, and I notice the reason for that probably is because they don't find the game similar to first DD1 and to have different aspects. As far as I can see those folks didn't even play the game enough to make such harsh reviews of the game, they simply give up after having to do some grind, which is sad cuz the game is very promising and fun.To begin with I must say that I never did any review about an early-access or beta/alpha games, but well ... like they say : there is always a first time.So here we go. The first Dungeon Defenders games come out a couple of years ago, and I never had a chance or time to try them out on that time. Just this year I had a chance to play it and without any surprises I immediately loved it. After getting all the collection I decided to also buy the upcoming Dungeon Defenders II, which is currently on alpha (I probably will update this review later), but for now the game is running really GOOD, So good that doesn't even feel like an early-access, As you can notice I got tons of hours already, that's all because the game hook you in, lots of fun playing solo or online, and will be even better when this goes F2P, cuz all your friends will be able to play it without spend a cent. Though I really reccomend this game as it is right now because it worth every penny.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I have played this game for a significant amount of time and I have finally come to the conclusion that I cannot recommend this game right now.Pros:So this game is kinda like a visual upgrade for dd1 which I played a lot on the 360 at the time and I enjoyed that game. The maps can have a pretty good learning curve and they can be kinda fun to play on. The gear can be pretty nice to get but later on in the game you will come to find the gear to just be frustrating in terms of the shear amount of rng on the rolls for different stats and so called "passives" which are suppose to give you buffs to certain builds. Then there is the characters. The characters are pretty simple. There are builds for each type of these heros that can make them fun and pretty viable late game(I say this now but Trendy are doing a lot of nerf passes as of late which is kinda why I am kinda done with this game for the time being but more on that later). Cons:There are a lot of problems for this game and I feel like the game devs can't use the whole "It's in beta or alpha" argument after the game being out for about 2 going on 3 years now. It is extremly buggy and each update seems to be adding more problems. Then there is the new heroes they have released. You can grind these heroes for this type of currency called "Defender Medals" which can be somewhat easy to grind for if you have a lot of time through the means of daily missions which reset at a wierd time for some in different time zones. There are also weeklys and monthlies but they haven't done a monthly in a good couple of months. Some say it is "pay to win" I like to call it "pay to skip" which is not that bad if you think about it. The gear at later levels can get really frustrating if you don't get the correct rolls. The devs keep just doing the nerf hammer on a lot of heroes and builds people run and barley buffing anything to a viable use. There are massive server issues and bugs that can make the game unplayable for some people for some length of time. TL:DR This game was a really cool concept and I liked playing it for the time being but it seems the way the devs are doing things at this point in time compared to the time was a payed to get access alpha the devs seemed to have lost sight of what this game was suppose to be. Until the devs either fix the the problems in the game or stop the nerf hammer on a lot of things and buff stuff to be more viable in endgame then I will still not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								This is a pretty good game, and heres why. - Fun to play characters.- Plays at 50 fps on my crappy computer on medium in some pretty intense moments. - Doesn't look like crap on medium or low- You can earn basically everything- People who pay get very trivial bonuses- Some sort of story that revolves around the four main playable characters- A decently done two-way crossover- Multiple challenges after the story is done- Diablo-esq loot system that doesn't seem heavily rigged in favor of pay to play players.Heres some cons. - Very short six act story, with 2-6 missions on average per act. - Challenges recommended directly after final boss seem infinitely harder than the final bosses stage. - Can't unlock any of the cool heroes even if you beat the full story, still gotta do those challenges for them. - Paying does give some convienient short-cuts, nothing bad though. - Story lacks general depth, but its alright for a game of this length.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are six reasons you buy and play a DD game. You love TD, RPG, loot farming, burning your life away, forgetting what the outside world looks like, doing the same thing over and over again, and have a tendency towards masochism. Every actual DD fan cannot deny the prior statement is true of themselves, and they know it. Moving on.What is actually wrong here:Content; believe it or not after 2+ years in "alpha" dev, the amount of content is sorely lacking. Namely endgame.Microtransactions; exclusively costumes are pay only, while new heroes/heroines are either 20$ish or replaying the same maps hundreds of times.Community; there are generally two types of players, those that have no clue what's going on, and those that are farmed and know what's going on. The two don't interact much and if they do the results are often less than fun.It's not a new story for the series but it's reached thinly vieled to in your face bad, at least for me. I can't expect Trendy to make any different decisions at this point and I can no longer support their business model.So, if you either have a deep pocket, or lots of time on your hands, I recomend you skip this one.

Early Access Review
								I have been following dungeon defenders II just for the love I had for the previous game. I was hyped at first few months of the game. but the developers are taking very odd decisions about this game. There is no real challenge in this game. You simply do the same content in different difficulties and skyrocket yourself to the highest difficulty which is NM4 atm. Then the game is simply over. You can get the best gear, still improve very slightly but the content does not change. There is no end-game challenge that keeps your mind working. This was supposed to be a strategy tower defense game with attacking hero mechanics but all I experienced so far is constant map zerg. They are releasing very cool new character every once in a while but that is it sadly. Some metas change in the way characters are built but the result never changes. I never have to think of a strategy. I can just put towers whereever I like and the map slowly melts before my eyes while I sit and browse the web. This is not the game I hoped this game would become.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								A sequel to the wildly popular and unique Dungeon Defenders game that takes a different direction from its predecessor.(Note, I originally did not recomment this game, but after hours of playing, I have decided to recommend it.  I'll explain why below.)Pros- Personal loot drops make for a more relaxed game where you don't have to constantly keep your eyes out for drops you need (There's no more race to grab the good loot before other players and that is a great design call)- The classes have some really cool attacks and abilities making each feel unique- Changes to mana and loot selling have made things much easier, both for sorting through loot and for upgrading it- Seperation of mana for building and for personal powers was a great call- Easy group finding system gets you right into the action- Reputation system makes random players more inclined to be polite- Synergy system means you can make powerful tower combinations if you have a cooperative team of players.Cons- Can't play offline- Long lags between games.  Due to the fact that a game has no clear leader, everyone has to ready up for the game to progress between levels and after the games.  This doesn't sound too bad, but when people go afk or someone new isn't paying attention, it can end up being 2+ minutes to continue on- Solo, each classes tower set is lacking (I'll explain more about this below)- A lack of mana will prevent you from doing much during a combat round (at least at low level)- The win points and fun-factor strategies to this game aren't as obvious as they were in the original- Builder specs feel very nerfed thanks to the lack of mana (EDIT: Again, this is only when you don't try to work with the other player's towers)- Maps are a bit bland, there aren't as many strategic points where you can put towers to have them cover multiple lanes- Tower synergies are esential to effective play- Certain specs are almost completely useless right now- Gating low-level players means that you can't power level your buddies.  It also means that, if your buddies get too far ahead, you can't play with them unless you make a new character.- Certain monsters outrange your towers.  I'm not sure if this changes at high level, but at low level it's extremely frustrating.  It means that you'll be babysitting your towers instead of being able to place them in different spots and trust them to do their job.- Due to the fact that you have to babysit your tower clumps, you cannot solo most of the levels (At least as an apprentice)So I went back and started playing as the monk with a friend who was playing the huntress, and I quickly figured out a pretty devistating combo that made the game much more playable.  I also figured out that one of my mages towers, while not super impressive when combined with his original towers, was extremely effective when combined with one of the monk's auras.So it seems the devs are really pushing for cooperative gameplay in this one, the game almost feels more like WoW than it does Dungeon Defenders.  To be successful, each player must assume a certain role in their tower construction.  A group of apprentice towers isn't very effective, however an ice tower combined with an electric aura (monk) combined with a water geyser (hunter) is devastating.  The concept is fun when it works out, the big problem is that new players or stubborn players will often build whatever they want, effectively lowering your chances of success.  I feel like this sort of design choice needs to be combined with a matchmaking system that tries to put one of each class in a game together.  (Maybe this is already the design, I don't know, but I was often in games with several members of my own class.)The good news is, I did start having a lot of fun once I figured out how the devs expected me to play.  However, I had to do a lot of digging to find that answer.  The game needs to guide its new players better so they know what's needed for victory and don't just build whatever, therebye frustrating the other people who are trying to work as a team.Also, the game needs more towers and more tower synergies.  As of this review, there is one devastating tower/aura/trap combination and everything else is very meh.  Certain towers are very meh and pretty much un-needed.  This needs to be changed so that there are multiple metas (tower building combinations) showing up in the games instead of just 1 or 2.In closing, the game is fun but very different from the first Dungeon Defenders.  You'll have the most fun when playing with friends, and you may want to watch some videos on how to effectively use your towers depending on your class.* UpdateSo the game changes quite a bit at high level.  Once you get your gear established and start the process of farming, you pretty much only need one skilled builder (generally an apprentice or squire) to do the tower setup for the level.  To be honest, it is kind of grindy and not always fun.  And while finding new items to improve your stats can be fun, the actual gameplay isn't.  This may change once more maps are available and harder difficulties are provided.  I'm going to keep my recommendation for now as the game isn't bad and still has potential, but I'm really looking for some new kinds of juicy cooperative gameplay.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								As with any Early Access game, make sure it is a game you are okay with it being changed as development goes on. As it stands, the game plays very similar to the first, with some minor changes. So far it seems to be living up to the greatness that was Dungeon Defenders 1.Understand that because it is early access, I know a lot of my concerns with the game will be fixed, and I will update my review when that happens.Pros/Cons:+ The AI seems to be smarter, and more dificult than those in the first game.+ The ability to move your hero while in place/repair/upgrade defense mode is amazing.+ The Dual Mana system is also an awesome addition. You now have mana for abilities, and a separate mana for towers.+ The new defenses each hero has are either upgrades from the first game, or new all together, which is good.+ The ability to vote for the next addition into the game is an awesome early access feature, and should be done more often by developers.- The gear upgrade system is lacking, and confusing at first. - There has yet to be added a proper tutorial system for new features.- The small amount of maps gets old quite fast, and the game tends to get boring after a bit.- Costumes and pets are nowhere to be found, and is one of the things that made the first game a favorite.- The gear shops are barely useful, as the only reason I use them is to get junk gear to upgrade my current stuff.All in all, the game is damn good, and can only get better from here.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've played the first one, it was great fun. This second one does a fantastic job building on what was great. Keeping what made it successful, yet deepening the gameplay, and setting itself up to become a very successful and long lasting experience.I've played the Pre-alpha so far, these days with so many Early Access floating around on steam, very few are actually entertaining for long periods of time and don't portray a very good picture of what the end product will be like.After purchasing it (based on the gameplay I've seen, and my experience of the first game) I read up on some of the difficulties the Studio faced, and as a member of a fellow game studio, I can understand their struggles, but I also commend them for making the right decisions to make the game they want to make for their fans.What I didn't know was that DD2 is intended to become a Free-to-play game. Even though I bought into it (with a 4 pack) which I think will work really well if done correctly, and it sounds like they got their heads on straight.I fully intend to cover this game in my future video guides, as I feel there may be enough depth to the game to make regular videos for fans.But one tip I can share right off the bat: PLAY WITH FRIENDS. It is infinitely more enjoyable, especially if you're around the same level. The matchmaking system is probably still in the works, so do yourself the favour, and don't expose yourself to potential malicious players who could ruin your experience. You payed good money, a good experience will allow you to justify it's current Early Access cost.Keep it up Trendy, you all deserve it!

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								The original Dungeon Defenders was likely one of the best executions of an integration between FPS and Tower Defense that the marketplace has seen.  I managed to clock a substantial quantity of hours into the original game, and it was an absolute blast to play.And then they started monetizing the game.  DLC became incredibly commonplace for addons.  New Heroes, new levels, new cosmetics, new character skins, anything they could think of.  They never directly monetized 'power', however, with the introduction of new levels with a higher level cap, it was an indirect way of power-capping new players.The other concern out of the implementation on the original Dungeon Defenders is that as new content got released, there was a substantial amount of Gear Inflation.  +500 to a given stat, which was godly at release, was trivial a few months later.  It had a much more MMO-esque grind to the game that drove their monetization strategy.Then we come to Dungeon Defenders 2.  When I look at this game, I realize that there were a lot of underlying engine upgrades, tons of texture updates, and they completely revamped multiple parts of the game... However, it's different enough from the original.  A lot of rehashed abilities, the same/familiar characters, etc.  The strength behind Dungeon Defenders 2 is that they have a better grasp of their monetization model going into it, and it's built that way from the ground up.  The reason Dungeon Defenders 2 is so popular right now is because it's still at it's infancy.  But even incredibly early on in the process, it really appears to be taking the same path at the original game, but by 'resetting' everything, they're opening the door for more monetization opportunies.  In my opinion, there hasn't been substantial innovation into this game to necessitate the high price tag, or recommend this game to anyone that has already enjoyed the original Dungeon Defenders.  It satisfies the same basic FPS-Tower Defense itch that can be scratched by cheaper alternatives in a more complete state.  This is much less a Dungeon Defenders 2, so much as it's a substantial overhaul of the original Dungeon Defenders.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Updated review (as of 01/28/17)Let me start by stating that I have never played the original Dungeon Defenders game.  So for me, Dungeon Defenders II (DDII for short) was my first experience with this franchise.  I have no knowledge of how DDI played and I will not be comparing DDI with DDII in this review.For me, DDII did something other Tower Defense games have never done.  They combined awesome tower builds with the ability to have a 3D environment that you (the character) can also run around and interact with.  This means that, in DDII, if you are not optimizing your towers as well as your hero damage and contributing both equally, you are not really playing the game the way it was meant to be played.The game also has its fair share of issues, like any other game, and itâs also worth mentioning that it is still in early access so anything I mention is subject to change.  When I started playing this game in mid-November of 2016, quite a bit had already been changed in DDII from the inception (or initial launch of the title).  For example, the campaign got a huge revamp right before I started and now it is designed to take you from lv1 to lv50 and get you started in Nightmare I difficulty out of the gate.  This was not the case originally.  The reason I mention this is, there is a massive update coming which will change and address quite a few issues most players have with the game, how you gear, progression within the difficulty tiers, inventory management, game balance and so much more.  Itâs important to understand, in my opinion, that the game is still early access and will continue to get better over time.All that said, I have really enjoyed my time with this game thus far and it is free to download so you can try it risk free.  I am so excited for the new changes coming in February 2017 (or later depending on TrendyENT) and I can highly recommend this game to anyone that likes the idea of a tower defense game that is much more action oriented.  Since I havenât really mentioned it, your character gears and levels up and it is very similar to diablo style games, loot based systems, where you are going to be grinding for better gear/drops so you can not only enhance your towers' defense power but also your hero power.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a load of crap. You want to try and tell me that this game costs $25, slap on an early access or pre-alpha tag and think you can get away with a fully functioning micro-transaction system? $50 micro transactions?! THATS NOT MICRO! YOUR FULL GAME DOES NOT COST THAT MUCH. Almost $10 for a single costume, and then more on top of that to unlock the alternate accessories? How about you guys actually focus on making and FINISHING the game instead of some cash shop items. Hell the $50 extra for the collectors edition upgrade is even more crap. 4 character skins, 4 tower skins (which aren't in the game yet) 10,000 in-game cash shop currency, and a title. You could spend that $50 and get DD1 with all of the DLC, or a 4 pack of DD1 and have even more fun with your friends.And for those of you saying "Well this is just there way of gaining support to make the game better." No, it's not. The collector's edition, maybe. Not this BS micro transaction crap. I already know where this is heading, there going to make the level cap high, and slow the leveling process to a halt halfway through. Then they start selling speed-ups, EXP, money, item droprate boosters. At the prices I'm already seeing I imangine they'll be $5 each, or a bundle pack for $10. Other games and other companies have pulled this same crap, and a lot of those were crucified by gamers. Just because they made a decent game once doesn't mean they should be immune to this. What happened to my character customization? Why can't I change my characters colors, put skill points into the towers and skills that I like the most? Because they monitized how your charcter looks and streamlined all forms of character building. Now you pick a character, name it, and that's all you get to do. Oh, but you get skill spheres. That's scool right? You get a total of 7 skill spheres: 3 small (stat boosters) 2 medium (tower/skill boosters), 1 large (tower/skill modifier), and 1 uber (huge boost to tower ability I guess). And that's it. That's all you get to do. There is no other form of customization, you don't get to level up skills or towers, you don't get to modify any of that crap. This is basic stuff that was in the first game. Why whould you take it away? Yeah, I get it, the game is pre-alpha (which is a BS excuse to ignore any problems people like me have considering how this game looks and plays) and a part of me really wants to like and enjoy it for what it is, but these terrible business practices will need to either change. I will not play this game ever again, and I will go back to playing DD1 as it is a more fun, enjoyable, and fulfilling experience, with or without friends. Do yourself a favor and go buy that. If you'll excuse I'm going to go put in for a refund now.

number of helpful: 22 of 42 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								6/10  For those who have invested many many many hours into the first Dungeon Defenders, heed my warning. This game is very much worse than the first Dungeon Defenders. It just does not offer much in comparison but since it is free (open alpha), feel free to try it out yourself.  I personally enjoyed this game a fair bit.This game was also very fun playing with friends and theory crafting strategies for beating maps we were having trouble on. Figuring out the most effective/efficient tower placements made it quite fun the first time around.After the initial 50 hours I started to grow quite boring and tedious to do anything and everything.The journey of getting your first max level character (level 50 at this point in time) is probably the most fun I've had in this game. Getting to max level and grinding out for the best gear you can and then replacing it instantly after climbing to the next Nightmare difficulty becomes less and less rewarding and feels like more of a chore.With everything I've said, this game is fairly fun for the first 30-50 hours. In that time you can: -Learn about the classes-You can reach max level on a character or two (or 3 if you're really diligent)-Learn about every map F I N A L   V E R D I C T All the maps are given to you and you can play them all before you ever reach max level.There is no real reward to reaching max level besides being able to start the Nightmare difficulties which are just a pain the butt and offer nothing new besides identitcal weapons with better overall stats.You get the feeling of "Oh great now I get to grind the same maps but its even harder...woop dee friggin' doo" I give it a rating of 6/10 and I'm listing it as a positive review because I did indeed have a lot of fun. It just gets boring with the lack of variety in "End Game"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
Early Access Review
 This is my third review of this game because I can not even PHATHOM why this newest update exists. With this newest endgame update, it sure did end the game for me. I don't even know where to start with this, so I'll go ahead and start with what I think the worst part of the update is about.  THE REMOVAL OF NIGHTMARE, THE ADDITION OF CHAOS So chaos goes up to chaos 5. Each chaos tier adds a brand new enemy type, ups their health and possibly even the wave sizes. Chaos 1 is extremely doable and is fair. Theeeen we get to every other chaos tier. This is where the game really goes belly up. My build is predominantly traps and auras at the moment. The reason? Almost every other projectile tower has turned into hot garbage after the update, either because they don't have enough crowd clear, attack too damn slow, or have pathetic damage. Auras and towers that are considered traps are where the real meat is, doing a decent amount of damage at a fast rate to a large group of enemies. Why did I just explain this to you? Just so you get an idea on what sort of hell you are facing on chaos 2 and above. Starting as early as chaos 2, they introduce EMP orcs. These â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥s can just spawn in a lane, do a quick windup where they slam their hammer into the ground, and suddenly every aura and trap within a 5 mile radius is stunned for 7 years (give or take). See the problem here? Unless you have a 5 man team of coordinated players who manage to insta kill the EMP orcs before they have a chance to EMP your towers, you're screwed kiddo. These guys render EVE2, monk, and huntress almost entirely unusable because most if not all of their towers are some kind of trap/aura. Did I mention they spawn in more than 1 lane? If you're someone like me that only plays with 1 other player, good luck dealing with these insects before they screw up an entire lane for you. So by that point, you are almost required to use a projectile tower or at least a dryad trap with good range. Oh but wait, whats this? Chaos 3 introduces a new annoying enemy type that completely blocks all projectiles? They spawn in every lane too?! AND have 1 million health?? Looks like that plan didn't last long. Again, this might be alot easier on a 4 man team, but this is an extremely cruel punishment for solo players. Oh, and they block projectiles from some heroes too, so I hope you brought a melee hero that needs to do a large amount of damage quickly to kill it as well as have enough health to not get blended by the enemies inside of it. Chaos 4 and 5 just add more annoying crap enemies to the mix that I won't even bother going over. Chaos 5 is basically impossible while 4 is an even bigger pain in theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥than 3. But thats not all, folks! WHAT HAPPENED TO INCURSIONS AND PASSIVES Disregarding the fact that they removed entirely different balanced 4 difficulty levels, lets move onto incursions. Originally, incursions used to be unique forms of missions that had you do a specific task or kill a special type of boss. They were brutal but possible, and rewarded excellent types of unique loot. This was because they could be done on nightmare difficulties. Now, this mode is locked to hard, meaning you get abysmal tier loot that will NOT help you in chaos. If that wasn't bad enough, the passives of alot of these weapons simply do not work anymore. The MAIN POINT of these weapons were their unique passives. The midas bow's gold drench passive is entirely gone, and its fully charged m2 flamethrower attack does NO damage. The monk's staff that gave him a cloud to fly on is entirely broken and only allows you to fly for 1 second. These issues and many others have not been fixed at all 8 days after the release of the update. Which ties into my last complaint: THE 1GB UPDATE THAT CAME OUT JUST TODAY Seeing as how there was a very large update today, I thought good things were coming, hopefully some nerfs to chaos and buffs to towers.  No.The update nerfed towers. It nerfed towers. Let that sink in. Broken passives weren't fixed and the acension bug that actually REMOVES slowing percentages were not fixed. At this point the game might as well be called "Barricades, Rams, and Flamethrowers oh my!" because these are the only towers viable anymore. Oh wait, you don't own abyss lord because the grind for medals is an incredible slog that takes weeks before you can afford a single character? Guess you'll be playing "Barricades and Flamethrowers" then. The game is like a burning building right now, and they are pouring gasoline onto it before grabbing some water to snuff it out. Even after these supposed 'big changes' (http://imgur.com/rNumAbr) go live, I doubt the game will be as good as it was before the update. I want nightmare back, I want nightmare incursions back, I want passives back, I want the old game back!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
Early Access Review
								Yet another good game doomed to fail because of a developer team that can't listen to even the most simple of feedback.Dungeon Defenders 2 was fantastic before the release of the Trials update, then everything seemed to begin snowballing downward. Not only was the initial jump from campaign mode to the new Chaos difficulty nearly impossible, but the people who managed to do not only that were punished instead of being congratulated. I'm sorry, but you don't reward players for getting to certain difficulties by randomly nerfing all the heroes and raising green mana costs on things that were just fine on their own. You do not make your new difficulty more difficult by making players weaker and making some heroes completely unviable.Another thing that the Trials update has done to doom this game is player scaling. In what screwed up universe is it a good idea to make your players feel like a burden just by playing with other people? The more people that join, the harder the Old One's Army gets. And it's not even to a challenging difficulty, a Chaos 1 or 2 map with four players is nearly impossible to beat, and it's gotten to the point where most people swear by the playstyle of "solo or nothing" because of how much of a burden playing with other people is. You've really messed up when people don't want to play with their friends by no fault of said friends. Trendy tried to fix this by lowering the scaling, but they refused to listen when their playerbase said "We want it GONE". That description I used for player scaling? It was referring to after the nerf. So even after they believed they had done good and entirely ignored their fans cries, their multiplayer-centric game still entirely discourages multiplayer.The loot scaling system is a damned mess to the point where most players in the chaos difficulty are just waiting around for the blacksmith or relic hunter to stock something that's even some semblance of an upgrade. Because apparently the very simple idea of "Stronger enemies and higher difficulty = better loot" is too bland and stupid for Trendy Entertainment. There are far too many stories about how players are confronted with the choice to either sacrifice all their shards because a piece of equipment is far better than what they have but has no shard slots, so they opt to just sit around and wait for the blacksmith or relic hunter to have something better. Waiting around for an upgrade despite having clearly earned it is not okay.Trendy doesnât seem to care about proper game care, either. Reports abound of gamebreaking bugs that have been occuring for months up to a year, and what has Trendy done? Absolutely nothing. They seem to have a complete and utter disregard for things that make an online multiplayer tower defense game what it is. I wanted to like this game. But I can't care about a game if the devs can't either.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's still in early development but already quite playable. For the players familiar with DD1 it's a feast of recognition and for those new into the world of "hybrid FPS combined with tower defenses" there's a tutorial and campaign easing you into the game.At the moment of this writing there's only 4 characters available, the same foursome from the original. But in true spirit the characters have aged a bit and no longer look like grade-school Southpark aged characters but more like teenagers. Quite a nice detail giving you the feeling of story progression.The game is still defend a crystal (see it as a homebase) from getting damaged by angry enemies. You can do this actively by killing them with your hero (the FPS element) or using your heroes defenses, arrow shooting towers, explosive traps auras and walls/barriers.Not all is quite finished yet. The way xp evolves at the moment is still a bit unbalanced the same if you compare the ratio of hero damage versus the damage traps/towers do. At the moment there's lots of ways to share your feedback via the forum and the developers seems to take the feedback into account.It's not a finished gem yet, but from what I can tell it plays a lot better than plenty of other "beta games" available on steam now.So if you can live with a few issues and enjoy playing either solo (doable) or with friends (co-op) then this can be a fun game

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have changed my review from a meh yes to a no due to lack of faith in the products future.Trendy, hot tip. Fix the core game before you make more content. It only gets harder and harder to go back and make the core good the more you stack a bunch of stuff on top of it. I keep returning to find more and more stuff, but it keeps feeling of lesser and lesser quality.This means tuning controls, menus, hub worlds, visual design choices...This means returning to DD1 and finding what was so fun about that game and infusing DD2 with it.This means adding controller support and splitscreen.And this means doing this BEFORE adding a bunch of levels and characters. Go back, look at the core. Fix it, then return to adding new stuff with the lessons learned from fixing the stuff you started with.I have returned to try out this game on MULTIPLE occasions hoping it had found its stride. I have been disappointed every time. I want this game to be good, it can be good. Everything is there to make it good, but its not good. Still no Controller support, the menu's look worse than they did before. The town is still huge for no reason. I don't want to buy anything because I don't have faith in the product. Give me the faith back, dig deep and find what made DD1 great and contrast it with what made Eterny-whatever suck. Pull it out, get it together, and then kill it. I want you to succeed. I want to play that game. I will come back and look at it and hopefully change my review to a resounding thumbs up. I have been waiting to throw a bunch of money at this game since it was announced.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								After quite a lot of time with DD2, the most important item of conversation I think should surround every review of this game is simple: Developers that listen to their players and act on it.I've been playing DD2 since closed beta early access, on and off. I'll go a few weekends playing almost non-stop, come back a 3 months later and the game is the same but different. It's always better. Little things here and there, big changes every once in a while, but always getting more polish, always getting better.That's what matters to me. They know exactly what kind of game they wanted to make and they made it, but they're open to player opinions and requests. Obviously they won't change everything based on what one person says, but if enough people share an opinion they make the change. That's really cool and is what keeps me coming back.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders 2 is a fun little game to pick up and play for short bursts of entertainment. Unfortunately that's all it is in its current state. With not much depth or difficulty, the fun can quickly turn into a boring grind for gear/currency/unlockables, all of which do not make much of a difference in gameplay.Every map has been mind numbingly easy, even on the "hardest" difficulty, and most of them can be cleared with a single Hero's defense towers. This can make for a very boring and lackluster session. It is a shame because the Heros do have some fun and interesting choices for defense, but they're just not needed in most cases.In my opinion, with the main flaw being lack of difficulty aside, DD2 still is a great game to own and play, especially if you have some friends to co-op with. Just don't burn yourself out by mindlessly grinding and instead focus on playing for fun-like using towers you don't need just for dramatic effect!

								Was good when my friends and I first played it but after coming back to later they have nerfed every good weapon in the game, removed skill spheres, made inventories a hassel to deal with, reset and redone leveling, made towers useless, and added a bunch of uselessâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥that nobody wanted or needed. Dungeon Defenders is supposed to be a laid back casual game where you set up a good defense and only help towers on especially hard levels. Now with 4 lvl. 50 characters previously able to solo The Buried Bastille without broken dlc characters *cough* Abyss Lord *cough* I can now barely make it through the first couple of levels on normal difficulty without having to babysit my defenses.Also unless I have overlooked something, they have completely removed fireball towers from the game and made them all â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ flamethrower towers that nobody ever liked or wanted to use. Rating pre-Lavamancer release: 8/10Rating post-Lavamancer release: Personally I would rate it at most 5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
Early Access Review
								Ever wonders what a game is like when the focus on getting cool items in order to survive only to spin it around to where items are only 10% of your character within 6 months of gameplay? Look no further for now you can play a game where all your hours are wasted and the core concepts are rotated on a 6 month basis.  Now for the second part to hopefully captivate you, creatures that are immune to attacks from the front specifically lead the charge while a conga line stream of enemies file in close behind to make a difficult concept even worse (the new update added the shield goblins).  So please enjoy collecting medals and grinding maps to get expierince instead of items which will only be completely changed waisting the majority of the time that you invest in the game and remember Alpha is the new Beta.Spoiler- If you were to take a roleplaying game and make it where every level required 1000 exp points to earn and each MAP earned you 1 exp point this would be what you would get, it's basically a 2 tier leveling system, in the beginning they treat levels like normal games then after 50 you now have "infinite" growth IE complete a hard map to get enough exp for 1 "ascension" level and the focus is on grinding your character and not on items.

								this game is awesome just like the first game, the only issue i have with it is that internet is required to play it solo, which means youll be fighting a boss, get it to 1000 hp (about 2 hits) and the game boots you loosing you loot, exp and any patiance you have with this game. if you have internet that isnt bad i highly reccomended. if, like me, you have rubbish internet then dont bother. get the first game instead, its awesome and you can play OFFLINE! to the game developers PLEASE make an offline mode! games that can be played one player but still needs online is silly and looses some fanbase who cant play due to rubbish internet. i love this game and have hundreds of hours in the first game, so far i got to level 4 on this during which time i was kicked about 10 times in 3 hours before loosing my patiance. i will play this again one day hopfully the game devs will make it offline, at which point i will more than happily change my review and let it consume my life like the first one did.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
Early Access Review
								This game is a perfect example of what happens when a dev team makes a really good game and then decides to get greedy and make a freemium sequel. In order to get any characters except for the first 4, you have to log in a solid 20+ hours across several days to get the currency you need for them from daily missions, or simply do what they want and buy premium currency. Along with that, the daily missions suckâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ You'd expect things like "deal x amount of damage within 10 seconds in a match" or "kill x enemies with y character" but nope, the only daily missions are "beat x maps of this theme" It's utterly stupid. On top of that, in the first dungeon defenders game, it actually mattered that you leveled each character up, got good equipment, and played your towers correctly. Now none of that really matters. All of your characters level up together now, which makes leveling up completely pointless at all. And then to actually do anything you have to "level up further" through ascension which is actually completely stupid. On top of that, the level cap for you and items is 50  (although I've never seen an item above lvl 46), and in order for any equipment to do jackâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥it needs to be upgraded, and all new equipment starts from 0. This game is an absolutelyâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥poor sequel to the first game, which was actually really good. Now, it's just a greedy company trying to get money.Oh, and one last note: the devs don't know how to balance forâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ and the game is absolutely FILLED with bugs and optimized horribly. I shouldn't be teleporting across my PRIVATE TAVERN when I'm BY MYSELF. Having lag when playing alone is horrendous. Oh, and the dev teams attitude towards patches sucks too. They literally will say "we know x bug exists, but we'll address that in the next patch." That's aâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥poor attitude towards the literal stability of the game.Last thing I want to mention: the campaign is really â¥â¥â¥â¥ing easy and doesn't require all the extra â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t I mentioned earlier. The campaign doesn't need you to upgrade your equipment 30+ levels to do anything, and it's easy enough to where the "balance" the devs try to make doesn't hurt you. The campaign itself is fun. Really fun. And it's worth going through some lag to play. I'd give the campaign experience an 8/10. The problem is that the campaign is like 15% of the game itself, where the rest of it is post game â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t that requires ungodly ammounts of grinding. If you're interested in this game at all, then I definitely recommend trying it and playing the campaign, because it's worth it. After that though, just stop and play something else, because there's nothing after the campaign worth trying to do.

								Pro's: -If you have a group of friends, its a very fun well crafted tower defense game.Con's: -To unlock the rest of the characters available in the game you either farm for an estimate 3~5 months, get lucky and gain some gems from their on stream giveways and maybe get enough gems to buy a character, OR buy gems in a total value of 95â¬'s just to unlock the rest of the 6 character's. -Even if you do spend the ridiculous amount of money on it or grind out the 3~5 months just to unlock the other character's, you might get one of their famous Lost Connection type of bugs, that will plague you until you have a mental breakdown and either delete the game or re-instal it in hopes that it will fix the issue, which it may, or may not, depends on how Trendy Entertainment feels like that day.

content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								I'll go straight ahead:Pros:-Graphics are alright;-Runs as smooth as butter in a less than average PC.Cons:-Bugs are taking forever to be fixed;-Good weapons and combinations are always nerfed;-The devs seem to be really interested in making us players farm for the rest of our lives for crappy gear;-This game has no progression at all;-Bought this game on early access while it was not f2p and received enough crystals to buy just two characters;-Microtransactions are painfully expensive;-The UI was changed three times already and it's still really confusing and misleading on matters like levelling up characters, pets and gear;Conclusion:Devs, you should listen to your community.It would've been better if you were to follow DD1's footsteps and it's approach on DLC. Although it was nearly impossible to play the first game without DLC characters, they were cheap and everyone used to buy them. Maps were far more memorable and new content was always highly anticipated.As a matter of fact, I've enjoyed playing DD2 on it's first year, but things have come to a point that this game is nearly unplayable and you are losing more players each day.

content:
Posted: April 24
Early Access Review
								I would have recommended this game before the Trails Update ruined the game. It alienated the people who invested time to grind out armor in the original game by givingâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥gems wilth little variety. There is A lot less individuality.Before:-You could have two of the same charaters with different builds, encouraging you to try different play styles for the same Character.-The Armor you received scaled the towers and charater to different builds. Allowing you to look for the gear that suits that individual charaters build (Tank, DPS, Wall, Tower DMG, Slow Tower, Debuff Tower, Anti Air) allowing for alot more grinding.-the game allowed for coordination with indiviual tower specing.Now:-You only need one Character (per Class) Because each tower is buffed by its own Talisman/Relic and your armor and weapon scale your health and damage. (Eliminating the Mulit character grinding and individual Tower Specing)-If Everyone is DPS, and Every Tower Speced where is the Individuality?-No one Needs to coordinate because everyone is speced to cover entire Lanes without help.Current Complaints:-The Mini Sheilds are â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t (They Block the Phonix from the archer completely Ruining her Wave clear. The Seige Rollers dont do that)-The Gems NEED to Stack if they are the same â¥â¥â¥â¥ing GEM.- Past Players are going to need more incentive to restart the entire game then theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥tier gems provided for Max level Gear. At Item Level 750 I could not play against Chaos 2 Because of the garbage gear I received. Other Comments:-I was a Fan of the Idea of Gems (Another thing to grind great!)-All of the new enemies I was happy with, besides the shield minions, If the sheild had health and could break awesome and instead of stopping any projectile that hits it.Misc:When is this game getting out of Alpha it came out in 2014?

Early Access Review
								The game was amazing and fun to play, untill the ruined it. The last big updates changed the game for the worst. All that i've farmed all that i acomplished is worthless now. And what do i get? A bunch of useless shards. Is that what i desurve? Is that what we desurve? For what we've done for this game till now? I don't know if i'll ever go back to this game again. Couse i don't like my work to be underpriced like this. For the question why do i even bother writing this is just for that little hope that maybe, the game will go back to normal, when it was fun to play, when you spend hours with random people and just have fun. But now it's gone and i don't know if it will ever come back. For those who are thinking should you play this game i'm not gonna tell you no, but remember that who knows what will happen in the futcher. Play at your own risk. That's all im going to say, have fun if you can.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II is the sequel to the popular tower-defense role-playing game, Dungeon Defenders. Like it's predecessor it has the elements of what makes a good tower-defense game.However, Dungeon Defenders II features a all new competitive mode which I've yet to tried out. (to be updated)Overall, I'd say its feels just like Dungeon Defenders,  the environment is much more beautiful to look at and the community is more lively which is a plus.It's a great game that I would recommend to veterans / new players to the tower-defense genre.

								I loved playing this game when it was first released for early access as I was a huge fan of the original. All that was lacking was content and replayability.I came back to the game recently and it's a mess now. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR It's not too bad to play if you can look past the p2w, just don't spend money on it. Not worth it.I've played for a long time, just not always on this steam account specifically. It's a geniunely good game, great concepts and all that. But it is leaning to that p2w side of things with microtransactions and overpriced heros and kits. It's great as a free game, but seriously, don't waste your money on it. They improved from the first dungeon defenders, but they're not quite there yet. The pay to win is ruining the teamwork and skill elements because if you have enough case, you don't need to work with people or have any skill.Plus it's been early access for at least a year by now? Probably longer. It wasn't even always Free to play either, it cost $50 at one point. But seeing as now it's free, it's not too much of a waste of time,  there still room to enjoy the game to a degree. But I have a lack of free time, so I play it maybe once or twice a week? Maybe if you play it every day, you'll get sick of it sooner.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I used to love first game so much. Already loving this one too, but speaking of its price for players who baught it. Its 15 euros,okay a decent price for this game, but seriously does it really needs to be payed for crap like skins ingame? I said 15 euros is a decent price,but it aswell is enough to not make people pay extra 9 euros (10 bucks) for one skin...what the hell devs, why so greedy? See for yourself,but I think its quite ridiculous for smtn like one damn costume. Game by itself is really nice and nothing to complain really except this little greedy thing.Pros:+Gorgeus fary tale graffics+Loot,lots of loot...I mean LOTS of it+Simple and interesting gameplay,easy to understand everything, even if you play first time+Soundtrack+Addictive in good sense,doesent get boring that fastCons:-No friendlist option ingame-Little stuff that you will want , but wont be able get as long as you wont pay extra real money

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								So coming from someone that played the first Dungeon Defenders way back when it came out I`m actualy glad to see a sequel that was done with such great care and polish. Great optimization, as always a nice design and detailed animations and excellent modeling. The soundtrack still keeps you in that state of living fairy tale. The dungeons are quite challenging later on and the skills still have a nice impact. You can feel your character growing in power with each upgrade. Also let`s not forget the loot: shiny, strong and eye catchy; the basis of any RPG.

content:
Posted: January 10
Early Access Review
								I had such high hopes for this game. I've been playing since the paid beta and the devs have just given us broken promises one after the other. The game isn't balanced what with required meta-gaming to push into nightmare 4 (highest game difficulty) followed by being able to steam roll through the endgame whilst using that meta, unkillable or unecessarily difficult bosses in recent updates. Also, for how long this game has been in development, and how active the community is at providing bug reports, why is it that with a strong computer system and internet connection my heroes are jumping all over the map? I cannot recommend this game until basic gameplay elements that should have been fixed many patches and months ago are revised.

								I had such high hopes for this game. I've been playing since the paid beta and the devs have just given us broken promises one after the other. The game isn't balanced what with required meta-gaming to push into nightmare 4 (highest game difficulty) followed by being able to steam roll through the endgame whilst using that meta, unkillable or unecessarily difficult bosses in recent updates. Also, for how long this game has been in development, and how active the community is at providing bug reports, why is it that with a strong computer system and internet connection my heroes are jumping all over the map? I cannot recommend this game until basic gameplay elements that should have been fixed many patches and months ago are revised.

								TL;DR It's not too bad to play if you can look past the p2w, just don't spend money on it. Not worth it.I've played for a long time, just not always on this steam account specifically. It's a geniunely good game, great concepts and all that. But it is leaning to that p2w side of things with microtransactions and overpriced heros and kits. It's great as a free game, but seriously, don't waste your money on it. They improved from the first dungeon defenders, but they're not quite there yet. The pay to win is ruining the teamwork and skill elements because if you have enough case, you don't need to work with people or have any skill.Plus it's been early access for at least a year by now? Probably longer. It wasn't even always Free to play either, it cost $50 at one point. But seeing as now it's free, it's not too much of a waste of time,  there still room to enjoy the game to a degree. But I have a lack of free time, so I play it maybe once or twice a week? Maybe if you play it every day, you'll get sick of it sooner.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Fun with a group of friends, but not that great for soloing unless you are willing to create multiple characters. Much like Dungeon Defenders 1, interactions between towers and the involvement of the player brings a new variable to what would otherwise be a traditional tower defense game. Average run length for each map is much shorter compared to DD1 (about 20-30min vs 1hour+) and the game overall is quite short, though there is decent replay value. Visuals and gameplay mechanis are much improved but the high degree of customizability that I loved from DD1 is reduced. Relatively a worthwhile purchase.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders 2 is a fun free to play game, with the option to "pay to get ahead". While at first glance when in game it may seem like new characters are inaccessible, that's a short term examination of the game. If every game only took two or three days, even a week to get everything in the game, you would stop playing. To start with everyone gets 4 character slots (assuming the player wants one of each class). Each character levels up when in your deck (4 hero slots, oh look less grind work) meaning when you start off and create one of each character (or whatever config you like) your first 4 heroes will reach maximum level at the same time. Simple beginnings no? After this comes getting good gear by playing endgame maps (working your way up the nightmare ladder). While you play however, you are also completing dailies, weeklies (monthlies will probably come back in a bit) and gaining defender medals. These medals can be used to unlock new characters (12000 the first two weeks for new heroes, 10000 afterwards, may eventually change) purchase special boosters (like pet love), keys (for the non paid costume and seasonal costume chests), powerful skill spheres, character slots (2000 each) or eggs (not quite yet, they are working on it). While characters might sound pricy, if you like the game you will easily play long enough to quickly obtain them and then be left wondering "what do i spend it on next?" The estimated time to obtain a new character at present is 3-4 weeks if your a brand new player that hasn't done any dailies. However they intend to boost the daily reward for a time from 150-250 per quest to 225 - 450 meaning that 3-4 weeks could be much shorter depending how often you play and events you participate in, giving any newbies a chance to jump headfirst in and get to the heroes they want. Overall, yes it's in Alpha, it's not the most polished or perfect game, but its damn good fun and they are working hard to make it not a product or service, but an experience that will entertain and spread enjoyment. They are aiming for 120 heroes, 6 down and 5 in the works, avg release time is one month inbetween characters. Every other week seems to be a release or event of some sort, not including special medal boosting weekends. This is my overview and recommendation of the game, hope it helps sway you in favour.

I am willing, nay eager, to pay $30-40 for a sequel - but I refuse to pay for gems, points, or widgets to make a lackluster base engine shine enough to make this work. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great Tower Defense with a lot of freedom. Played it with some friends, had some fun.Heroes can be played various ways, tower defense, dps, one of my friends went tanky knight. I especially like the freedom of tower placement. You can place towers almost anywhere in the most bonkers placers. MIght not be efficient, but fun. In contrast to let's say Orcs Must Die where trap placement is restricted to certain places more or less (though a good game on it's own). Difficulty was alright. The beginning was really easy. Depending on the amount of people you play with it gets harder as you progress (we were not powergamers who let themselves get carried, so if you do that you might skip difficulties entirely). Overall a great game. The only thing it is lacking are maps. There are some server issues but apart from long loading times there wasn't anything serious. D3 had more performance problems than this game.There is some criticism that I think is unfair and I want to adress it from my point of view.Some say overpowered characters are locked behind a paywall. In my opinion this is simply not true. Apart from a business perspective (it's free to play afterall) we found the gathering of ingame currency quite easy. There are daily quests and can stock up 3 of them + weekly quests. The lowest amount of currency for a quest is 275 (you can reroll a quest). You need 10000 to unlock a new character. So in 30 days logging in 10 times you should have a new character.So in my humble opinion anyone who thinks this is a paywall or considers this grinding has never played a game with actual paywalls In fact while I write this review I doing my daily quests on a low level map almost completely afk.While these new characters are really strong they don't lock other characters out from content. We did all content perfectly fine with the original 4 heroes. There is a balance patch coming in a few days that is supposed to bring the old heroes on par with the new ones. I really like this approach. Other developers opt for the other way. For example Path of Exile (a Diablo-esque grind ARPG) does the exact opposite. They nerf their content until it is no longer playable.We were satisfied. It was fun and we are sure to check back when there is more content.PS: Yes, the store prices are bonkers and I hope they restructure them once they get more content rolling out.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great Tower Defense with a lot of freedom. Played it with some friends, had some fun.Heroes can be played various ways, tower defense, dps, one of my friends went tanky knight. I especially like the freedom of tower placement. You can place towers almost anywhere in the most bonkers placers. MIght not be efficient, but fun. In contrast to let's say Orcs Must Die where trap placement is restricted to certain places more or less (though a good game on it's own). Difficulty was alright. The beginning was really easy. Depending on the amount of people you play with it gets harder as you progress (we were not powergamers who let themselves get carried, so if you do that you might skip difficulties entirely). Overall a great game. The only thing it is lacking are maps. There are some server issues but apart from long loading times there wasn't anything serious. D3 had more performance problems than this game.There is some criticism that I think is unfair and I want to adress it from my point of view.Some say overpowered characters are locked behind a paywall. In my opinion this is simply not true. Apart from a business perspective (it's free to play afterall) we found the gathering of ingame currency quite easy. There are daily quests and can stock up 3 of them + weekly quests. The lowest amount of currency for a quest is 275 (you can reroll a quest). You need 10000 to unlock a new character. So in 30 days logging in 10 times you should have a new character.So in my humble opinion anyone who thinks this is a paywall or considers this grinding has never played a game with actual paywalls In fact while I write this review I doing my daily quests on a low level map almost completely afk.While these new characters are really strong they don't lock other characters out from content. We did all content perfectly fine with the original 4 heroes. There is a balance patch coming in a few days that is supposed to bring the old heroes on par with the new ones. I really like this approach. Other developers opt for the other way. For example Path of Exile (a Diablo-esque grind ARPG) does the exact opposite. They nerf their content until it is no longer playable.We were satisfied. It was fun and we are sure to check back when there is more content.PS: Yes, the store prices are bonkers and I hope they restructure them once they get more content rolling out.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Take this review (like you should with all reviews) with a grain of salt. I played Dungeon Defenders 1 back in the day on the Playstation with my bro and enjoyed it greatly. When DD2 was announced, I had a trip of nostalglia back ot the good ol' days. Initially, I got a chance for early access and didn't really like what I saw. There was so many issues with it, it wasnt worth the time or effort to play.Fast forward, I'm now playing this game with my bf and his friends and I really enjoy the game again. Its really not a game for lengthy play throughs though. I get easily bored of the same maps after a while and can predict where all the major issues with waves come into play.That being said, its still a great game and still a good strategy tester. I even love the predictability of the waves which allow me to mess around with different characters and their tower strategy. This game has room to grow and has shown that it can grow. Dungeon Defenders will always have a spot on my game shelf.

content:
Posted: April 11
Early Access Review
								tl;dr: Life's too short to expose yourself to this level of amateurism and immature design.Elaboration: I'm a huge Tower Defence and RPG fan. Childish and immature artwork irritate me greatly, but due to the former I was willing to look past that. I wanted DD2 to be good so badly that I've played it more than 100 hours, yet ended up enjoying little of it.It used to be decent. Childish, simplistic and casual, but also refreshing and unique. The servers were always a mess, bugs were everywhere and the game's UI was horribly inefficient and lacking in important information/functions.Since then, they've pushed for more content updates, ignored all the game's problems and implemented a Shard System which is so horribly unappealing and unusable that whoever designed it should be fired for gross incompetence.This is the last time I'll ever look back at this game, and probably the last time I have to: It's dying. Good riddance, moving on.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've stuck with this game for over a year, have been very active on the steam forums and after 600+ hours of play, am very familiar with it.The short version is: I can't recommend this game to anyone.The long version is:BugsThe devs don't prioritize fixing the game at all. Bugs that have been in the game for over a year persist, broken meta goes unchanged for 8+ months, etc.They started a site dedicated to reporting bugs, that has pages and pages of bug report threads that never get addressed vs the very few pages of things that supposedly got fixed, and of those a lot of them reoccur. There's even things that are clearly broken, but they refuse to fix because they deem it "working as intended".The most infamous one is the "back to tavern" issue, where if just 1 player out of 4 picks it, and the other players had picked "replay", it will ignore what the other players wanted and force them to town, which for some people will also go into the "falling off the world" glitch or the "infinite loading" glitch.They refuse to acknowledge that the "back to tavern" thing is an issue because they meant it to work like that, even though a far better solution would be to just make the players that pick that option break off the party and return to the tavern on their own while the rest just replay.The most random things will break during updates as well, often when adding a new map, skills or abilities will stop working. Every update breaks far more than it ever fixes.Unethical treatment of players/customersThe main reason I give up on this game is because the devs have no respect for the time the players put into the game.The game has 3 currencies: Gold - used for upgrades, but kinda worthless otherwise.Medals - harder to get, used to buy new characters, exclusive pets, keys to the free cosmetics, boosters. Has a cap of 12000 for some reason.Gems - Normally only obtainable with real money, but a small amount is given as a 1 time only rewardOn the campaign revamp update, the devs made it so that new players could earn 5000 medals by the time they finish it. Veteran players were denied those with no real justification.On the trials update, the devs decided to remove spheres, some of which cost medals, between 250 and 5000 of them. Instead of refunding the players' medals, they gave them gold instead of the medals the players had earned, which is an unacceptable substitute as it's easily obtainable by playing the game normally.The same update revamped the inventory system, and if you previously had bought a bag with gems (which is the currency that you buy with money), you could had potentially ended up with the same storage space as someone who just started playing.Again, no refund.Both were situations that could had been VERY easily solved with very few lines of SQL. So we have to conclude they did this intentionally.The game runs entirely server sideProbably to prevent cheating, the game runs on the server. You client merely sends instructions to the server.The problem with this is that if there's any lag between you and the server, the gameplay is jittery, and your character will teleport around, often flinging you off cliffs. The netcode, if there is any, is awful.Moving can feel awful, and sometimes you're so afraid to teleport around you don't want to move.It's very likely the devs don't play their own gameOn Xmas 2016, they introduced a new enemy by surprise: a siege roller. This enemy isn't invincible, but was riddled with bugs and caused a ton of issues.Some skills just didn't work on it.It forced a tedious meta on all players for almost 3 months.Some heroes simply could not deal with it.It would instantly destroy trap type defenses, which is half of the defenses in the game.They would spawn as a replacement for ogres, but where nowhere near as easy to deal with, making the difficulty absolutely random, and for some players, potentially unbeatable.The hitbox was almost inside the damn thing, and hard to hit with melee characters.They put that into the game, and went on vacation the next day. Not that it matters because once they got back, they still didn't fix it til 2+ months later.On another update, the devs made poison dart towers (PDTs) extremely overpowered. a week or 2 later, they nerfed them, but they still remained the most powerful defense in the entire game, trivializing every map/difficulty for over 8 months.This was reported in playtesting, and several times on the bug report site (the poison from PDTs would stack twice for some reason), and they just let it ride like that.Art direction is becoming inconsistentThis is minor, I'll admit, but it's worth noting. And it's not just the art, but also the animations.For months, rather than fixing bugs, the devs seemed oddly focused on releasing new heroes.However, it started becoming more and more noticeable that they were cutting corners. For example, the models for the lavamancer, mystic and dryad could not look up and down like the other heroes, as a result they could attack in those directions either.The towers for the mystic and the dryad only have 1 model and don't change with upgrades.The dryad's hero model in particular doesn't match any of the other females in the game (proportions), and is really tall for some reason. However her portrait is astonishingly bad and looks like something out of a crappy newgrounds flash game.If the art style is what attracted you to the game, don't expect them to keep it up because the artist that did the first few heroes and bosses/enemies isn't working with them anymore.It's not a very fun game once you're in the endgameThis is actually a rather slow paced game and kinda tedious.Getting to the later difficulties is a challenge, and that's fun. But, being in the endgame for months with no challenge made me realize that this is a slow game, and essentially not that fun.The trials update might replace the very little skill is in the game with grinding, and that honestly sounds even worse.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I played Dungeon Defenders 1 on the X-box 360 I enjoyed it, until it came to multiplayer and experienced nothing but hackers and modders. However here in Dungeon Defenders 2 I can honestly say that I have found my new haven in the video game community. In my first week of playing I felt all of the nostalgia from DD1 rush back. I quit many other games that I had invested (easily) hundreds of dollars in, to start this game and dedicate myself to the immersive game play that Trendy (and Etheria, the Realm they created) are known for. The game is, hands down, on the top of my list for games. I have invested (proudly, I might add) to the continuation of this games developement. This is the open Alpha, and there is nowhere to go but up for this game.Obviously, the game is Grind intensive, but you get out of this game what you put in. In my first week I had 5 level 50's and 700 iPwr on each of them.Overall, I heavily recommend DD2. I hope that our friends here at Trendy continue the great work and continue to amaze us with new content. Happy Hunting!
