content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Posted: 2014-12-19Probably one of the better defense games i played. Was well worth the price if you enjoy this genre of games. And for a "pre alpha" this is one polished game. glad to have picked it up during early access.Update: 2015-04-26Developers are constantly keeping up to date with new patches and content, as well as interacting via twitch on upcoming goodies :P This game really is alot of fun with a group of friends or even randoms. It offers that itch i've been looking for.Like i said before it is well worth the money. I realize that the goal of the developers is to make it a free to play which will allow them more options in the future, but currently its in "pre-alpha" and im not sure when it'll change to alpha or even beta. so if you think it looks like something you'd like. i'd say go for it. this was my first free to play purchase that i've made. And at first i was like great its going to be free to play, and yet i bought it. But i'd have to wait for this extremely fun defense game to come out.Pros:-Developer Interaction via Twitch-Increasing amount of content-Great art style-Fluid Gameplay-Fun Co-op Experience-Teamwork is essential :P-Current community is greatCons:-Minor bugs (but hey, its pre alpha :D)-Not as much fun solo-Some difficulties/maps almost impossible solo-Currently a small communityUpdate: 2015-07-28Ill be 100% honest. If you played DD1 this game may not be for you. i never played DD1. It seems as though everyone who has, has become disappointed with the turn out of this game so far. i haven't play much as of recently, but being new to the Dungeon Defenders franchise, i really like this game so far. Which probably means i'd love DD1.Its still a great game. Has bugs. Starting to see microtransaction creeping in which no ones a fan of. But so far it has a great community and i like how its turning out. Maybe wait till it goes Free To Play before you give it a shot? but i felt it was worth what i paid.

number of helpful: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is an addicting game formula, match up with people, grind for perfect loot Diablo-style until you want to cry.As a tower defense game, it is lacking. It's more of a tower defense-lite. You can not select priority on your units, so your towers will likely focus on goblin fodder on the ground while a flying bomb passes overhead and goes straight for your objective.The AI is a joke, many of your losses will be due to just straight up horrible AI.This game is in one word; broken. I crash at least a dozen times a day, and that is not exclusive to my experience, this happens to everybody. Trendy refuses to acknowledge it. Instead they sweep it under the rug while they continue to release more content.Trendy Entertainment as a studio is a total failure. This game is being begrudgingly birthed out of the UDK engine while Trendy Entertainment sits on live stream and straight up admits they have no idea what they're doing.Recently Trendy Entertainment sued Ark development team for a whopping 40 million dollars, while I believe they were 100% justified legally, I fail to see how this money is being used to improve their game. Nothing has changed, this game is still cobbled together by misshapen, broken lego bricks. You'd think when a company makes more money in a suit then they have ever made in their entire existence that you'd see some sort of change.All in all, I recommend this game, and I don't know why. I have 500+ hours and I will continue to play it. I really wish I could explain why I enjoy it, seeing as I spend most of the time playing being frustrated by how broken everything is, but I can't.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is my first real try an actually review please tell me how I can do better and what you think thanks.I have really enjoyed this game there are four characters to choose from right now the original four from the first huntress, apprentice, squire and monk there are two blank portraits for heroes so hopefully they come out soon and free (it's early access so it better come out free) I would say that if you liked the first one this one is worth getting. So far I've encountered one bug over and over where certain mobs will get stuck on a wall or in a object along the way toward their objective. they just added pets and the first boss for this game hopefully it continues to get awesome updates. Today (the day after I wrote  this -,-) they added pets, a custom shop which you can use "gems", which you have to buy with real money, to buy costumes,they also added the first boss in the alpha so far and a sphere system which give your heroes bonuses.  Differences from Dungeon Defenders   Graphics could be good depending how you feel about it  Monsters drop less Mana to build towers with (makes the game a lot harder)  Tavern has more than just one shop keeper  You can only have three characters to switch between mid game  Leveling stats, you get to choose passive type things instead of stats for your hero/towers  The main objectives you have to protect are more than just crystals plus you have sub objectives to protect which keep extra spawns from opening   Hero combat is a lot funner than it use to be  You can move around and fight while building, repairing and upgrading   Pets are dropped as eggs and you have to wait eight hours for them to hatch (one at a time)  can level your pets with pet food and having them earn xp  In game currency bought with real money called "gems" can be used to buy costumes right now  Monsters will get stuck behind each other messing up lanes (hopefully fixed soon)  You have to use your hero in combat some monsters can out range your towers so if you don't do anything they will get destroyed    Overall it has an enjoyable experience       You can watch my video on it here: 


YouTubeâ¢ Video: Pman tries Dungeon Defenders II (early access)Â 

			Views: 57		

			The key differences between this and dungeon defenders are really just the tavern change, graphics change, and the improved combat thanks for watching guys!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Everything wrong with the game below.Had to quit my match on the throne room because malaysia was having typhoon problems and it disrupted the server causing so much lag stepping and teleportation, It was just unplayable. For some reaon there is no AUS server.Also this needs to be adressed to the developers ASAP. I spend more time cleaning out my bags then playing the game due to the insane drop rate on loot. its absolutly ridicolous that my bags are 70% full after 1 round of a 7 round map. Each round increasing the enemies meaning even more loot will just drop. The loot rarly drops anything useful meaning you will spend most of the time wasted even checking what you get because you know it's not going to be very good. the game dosn't even have a auto sell lower stat items so you have to spend even longer manually clicking on EVERY SINGLE item you get. I Have many times often sold my only good loot i got becuase i just click on everything fast to auto sell because the good to bad ratio on loot is like 1/100.   Legendary weapons don't feel legendary when you come across a new one every 5 minutes and every fkn 10 seconds you get an annoying prompt on your screen saying mythic loot has been dropped. Mythic loot is just slightly better loot that just adds up to flooding your bags even faster then before. The loot system needs a rework ASAP.another reason why loot should be reworked is it scales for the enemy level and not your player level. The developers gets this impression that you will be leveling at the same pace as the enemies and that you will fail levels untill you get stronger. this is not the case. the game is EXTREMLY EASY and your characters don't level up as fast as you progress through the game. My friend and i outscaled the game at around lv 10. I am forced to use loot 10 lvs under my character lv becuase the content we are doing only drops loot that is way to high to wear. We cant even keep the good pulls because it just clogs up your bags which will be full in another 5 mins so you are forced to sell. the game desperatly needs a bank to store this high lv gear. It got to a point where we were easily doing IPWR 150 over what the game recommended for us. It also feels like the only reason you even need a DPS character is becuase you are doing content 150 IPWR higher. If you matched the IPWR lv you can easily throw down a couple of towers and just AFK. the in map traps are good idea but are so useless i forget to actually use them. stratergy is limited to: Place a wall here with a tower behind it and place a anti air tower at the crystal. I have come up with a few more stratergys such as placing walls infront of other walls so you towers dont take collateral damage from the ISIS goblins. But even even after inventing these I cant possibly think of much more to do. This is pretty much the only stratergies you can do because the game has many unviable hero moves and towers limiting you to like 1 or 2 options out of 4 for both buidlings and ablitly moves. All in All fun game, but i hope some of these features will be fixed before full game release.

number of helpful: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Looking for out-of-the box game that has features of a Hack n'Slash, MMORPG and Tower Defense? This is the game for you! It is casual (but rewards those who put their time into playing it), it has excellent equipment system with amazing variety, decent hero progression and a lot of tactical planning. You can play it solo (it allows you to create your own "party" of heroes), with friends or with some random people. Despite it being an alpha version, the game is perfectly playable and offers hours and hours (and hours) of content. Constant updates keep the game balanced and add lots of content. It's very intuitive (apart from map selection but well, it's an alpha after all), the engine is solid and the game as-such is quite nicely balanced. It's definitely worth supporting. The only comparably good Tower Defense game I have ever played is its predecessor, Dungeon Defenders 1.

Early Access Review
								This game is garbage compared to the original Dungeon Defenders. I have 175 hrs into this game already, uninstalled it and will not look back, and I still have like $30 worth of gems or whatever but I don't even care anymore. Game was just NOT FUN. I gave it more time, waiting update after update, game play didn't improve at all. Not sure what they can do at this point to fix this game. If they made something similar to DD1, I might come back, but holy crap I am disappointed with this.EDIT 3/1/2017I decided to install the game shortly before this new update because it sounded VERY interesting. I was actually enjoying the game again to my surprise, and was eagerly waiting for the update. Turns out, I had my hopes up too high and the update pretty much ruined the game for me again. No tower range, super grindy now in order to get ascension levels, crappy UI, bugs all over the place. I don't get it, why take away tower range? It doesn't feel like tower defense anymore, it's just running around with your hero and trying to kill stuff before your walls get taken down. Yep I am aware of the range shard you can get. Why make it a shard if everyone is going to need to slot it in their towers?  That's like something mandatory that they felt like removing for no reason. Towers became useless, traps useless, they just get runned over by the siege roller, attack aura useless, same deal with traps. Hey at least the walls are good. So stupid, uninstalled again. Maybe gonna wait another year and try again to see if they fix the game for real.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II... Thou i could not personally say much as i basically only have a level 4, i will say what i do know.This game is awesome in many aspects, it rebuilds the foundations for which original Hero's were made. This is certainly something i almost did not expect with the Abyss Lord, also refered to as "The Summoner *Dungeon Defenders*.However, the only thing that i do feel about this game that is diffrent and may make this feel lacking is the scale of where and what you can build, and defense area. I could be just saying that, because i'v only seen the small maps. But when i really think and feel about it, i can't defend as natrually as i'd like to.For anyone just starting out, this game and many others will basically feel like a game not worth your time, but i strongly suggest you rethink what you have said, if you put in as many hours as i did on the Original game, you might find that the higher your level, the more fun you start having, and the more balanced things start to feel.In the Original game, i had the Jester, Hunter, Summoner, Barbarian, Countess, Squire, Huntress, Ev Series 1, Monk and most of them i got to either level 100 or close. This is when you start setting a goal for the ULTIMATE gear which takes waves and WAVES of time to loot. The fun part is, that while your farming for this loot, you acctually get a chance to think about defense Stratagys, and maybe even what you should primarily upgrade your gear to. Personally, i started throwing all my points into Countess and Hunter for Defenses, The Monk was Area of effect and tanky ammounts of life or defenses collapsed. Also Ev for her buff beam... Yeah, the good times.I never offically started having the fun of my Life till i hit the level 80 mark, but when i did, i started thinking about playing the game all over again, maybe even with my friends :)I'd Recommend this game, and can't wait till i get ALOT of spare time to play it, also can't wait to play it with my friends.PS: I felt i had to say something, because thou i am not enjoying the game at this current point in time, i do enjoy building a character and enjoy playing more with friends. Thank's for your great and Admirible understanding!

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I got hooked into DD1 after playing the first mission. After I finished the game and modded the crap out of it, I played dungeon defenders eternity and fell in love with it all over again.This sorry excuse for a dungeon defenders game is just that. A sorry excuse. The graphics may be 'nicer' (I personally prefer the look the old games had), and it may be less prone to awkward crashes, but damn. At the very least, DDE had some half/decent gameplay to go along with it. Back to my point about being hooked at the first mission. I played through the tutorial level as the sorceror (which was my go to character considering how the summoner was yet to be implemented) and after putting up with the crappy enemy spawn times, the crappier enemy walking pace and the even crappier enemy damage (despite not having any armour at all), I uninstalled it and am glad it's no longer taking up space on my SSD. I did head back to the hub world, but got lost as to what I was doing. The UI was wonky and difficult to navigate, the new systems failed to improve the solid old ones and there was basically no point to having such a massive scale revamp.It makes me even angrier that my favourite hero from DD1/DDE, The Summoner, had the one gimik that made his character interesting and different from the rest removed. In DD1/DDE, The Summoner had the ability to summon crystal versions of the enemies in place of towers. These crystal enemies has the ability to move and even chase enemies. Despite the AI for your minions being wonky and just plain broken at times, the gimik changed the flow of gameplay and allowed for such a dynamic sense of strategy. Suddenly, if my tower went down and I had no mana to replace it, I could choose to relocate some of my other minions to it's job. This was such a cool and different mechanic, and I loved it the instant I started using it.NOW, The Summoner (as of the writing of this review) has had his best quality removed. All his towers function like towers and blockades, which is a huge let down and a shame. On top of that, he lost his other two great abilities which allowed easy surveying of the battlefield, namely his "Phase Shift Overlord" ability, which turned the classic 3rd/1st person perspective into a top-down look of the entire battlefield. He could even summon and move minions from this perspective, once again adding to the extra gameplay elements. But NOPE, Trendy thought it would be a good idea to remove the interesting mechanics they had set up in the previous games.Trendy, get your act together. I'm happy that you're not actually charging anyone to trial what is essentially a shiny pile of garbage compared to your previous works, but seriously. What happen to the old magic, that made DD1/DDE so good?

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off this game is in alpha. This means that the game still has issues and isn't feature complete. TL;DR The game has a few issues but is still quite good.I have enjoyed this game so far it has many features I enjoy more than Dungeon Defenders 1. The gathering mana system has greatly improved. Instead of going around to all the chests on the map you just have to interact with one. The other thing about the mana system that is a huge improvement is that you don't lose mana when you pick up a large chunk for example, if you only have space for 5 mana left and you picked up 10 in DD1 you would lose 5 mana in DD2 you gain 5 mana and 5 mana drops on your player. The only issue I have is with dropping mana, you can only drop 10 at a time and there is no drop all mana button.The sub-core system is fantastic in my opinion. You can easily just build up around your main cores and deal with extra mobs released from destroyed sub-cores or you can spread your defenses out more, take that risk and the payout is a fair bit more exp.The skill / tower build system now gives you four options instead of five. This is both a pro and a con to me. The fewer skills and fewer towers you have, the more balanced the game will be. This is because it will be that much simpler to balance, but on the other hand that extra skill or extra tower would be nice. The placement system for some of the monk's auras are slightly aggravating. If you build the monk's auras first you can then place traps or towers quite close to then, however if you build traps or towers first then you can't place the auora in the same spot as if you did the order the other way around. On a side note all the towers look quite nice.Mob pathing seems to be fairly good. I have had a few issues where mobs get stuck behind the spawner wall and have had to use skills to kill them. I get the occasional mob stuck on a wall but as the game development progresses I am finding this to be less and less of an issue. Also flying kobolds areâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥holes.The maps are pretty exciting. They look quite nice and every map has it's environmental traps. The environmental traps can also be activated from a player shooting at it which is nice for when you can't get over there in time but there have been a few times when a stray shot has activated it. The maps are also where the game shows being in alpha a little bit. There are still a few ways to get outside of some of the maps, but as of the latest patch (November 21 2014) many of those have been fixed.Solo play versus group play is a huge difference. The ideal way to play this game is with a party of four. This is due to the item drop system giving higher chances to parties with more people in it. The game still lacks a trade system that makes me sad, but it looks like it's coming. There are references to it in the config files for the game.I know there is content missing and I am looking forward to seeing how the game development progresses.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off, I love this game, and it's constantly being updated to become just as addicting as its predecessor.  Genre:  Tower defence with loot finder elements.  Pros:  (- Level up system:                       * Ability points.                       *  Different towers.                       *  Stat increases.                       *  Gear level Requirments.)- The combined genre of TD (Tower defence) and Loot Finder make this game extremely unique.- Up to 4 player coop which might be increased to 6 or 8 player on select maps in the future.  - Great graphics.- Four different hero classes.  Some might complain about this in comparison to DD1, but again, there will be more hero classes in the future.Neutral:- Non boostable leveling.  This is something that I can't quite tell if I like or not.  Allow me to exaplain...- In the first game, if you wanted to level up a character very quickly it could be done easily by setting up a defence with multiple high level heros and then switching to your level one to instantly hit around level 70 after maybe 4 waves, depending on your setup.  In DD2 this is not possible, your character level is capped with a maximum level difference between both characters of 5.  Cons:  Last time I played the game was still in Pre-Alpha, might be in Alpha now, and these cons will repesent the game in Pre-Alpha.- No kicking system.  Nothing grinds my gears more than when someone ques up for coop and afks.  - No Pets.  I miss my treadmill buddies.  Maybe we'll get some elliptical pals this time around.- No survival mode as of yet, I'm sure they'll get around to it soon though.- No outfits yet, not much of a con.It's very difficult to think of cons for this game.  Eventual pro:The game will eventually become free to play with microtransactions for cosmetic overrides.  If you buy it now you'll recieve in game credit for what you paid! I highly recommend this game.  I love it.  Recommend buying with friends!

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Played the game a bit already, 40hrs+, I like it. I personally played DD1 quite a lot.About DD2:Pros:F2P (Free To Play), with NO P2W (Pay to Win), Only Pay to boost, making life a lot easier, such as extra bags, more character slots and cosmetics, Defenders pack is worth it, and if you bought this a lot earlier you probably got some extra bags from that.  (I dunno if they will change this view)Less towers, Less characters than DD1, Making life simplier than DD1 end game, which was basically 1 misplace and you got ruined...If you played DD1, and you liked it, then I highly recomend it.Very short Bugged Enemy Timer compared to DD1 which had like 10 minutes.... Yes that's a PRO!ConsEXTREMELY limited build options at start of end game (NM1-NM2), requires specific gear, they are currently balancing drop rates, but I think the build options should be required at the end stage of Game rather than start of End GameGrinding, If you don't like it. I recomend you go away....Very small inventory space, in DD1 you had an entire Tavern to fill, Gems must be used to get more inventory sadly, I think its a con. but hey, at least you get to a F2P game.Laggy as hell sometimes {Doesn't matter computer}, please note that they state the game is in alpha, although the game content is like DD1 when they first released it, it has enough content to make you spend several hundreds of hours for grinding, but for just campaign? then no don't buy it.Would I recomend?Do you like Tower Defense in 3rd person?Do you like to DPS?Do you like to Grind?Do you like to Grind even more?Are you a grind-a-holic?Did you like Dungeon Defenders 1 (Or Eternity)Do you like Sanctum but wanted more of a fantasy setting?are you a Unreal Engine lover? (I think DD2 is unreal engine, at least DD1 was)If you answered yes to any of the questions... then YES II RECOMEND IT!----------------------------------------------------------------------EDIT - 2016 - July 26thIn terms of New Characters, Game is still PAY TO BOOST AND NOT PAY TO WIN! the only thing I noticed that is like pay to win is bag space which costs money and some skins..... but this game is still PAY TO BOOST! Game rather requires you to farm every day for medals to unlock a hero which you gain a hero slot so in the end you can get lots of characters without needing of buying gems so that's a plus (don't know if it was possible pre-medals)Game is rather GRINDY! and options are still RESTRICTED to specific builds and sadly there are no guides for the moment that is up to date with builds, was thinking of making this in a few weeks.  sadly they get out of date rather quickly due to updatesalso people complaining about updates, you really really havn't played for more than a week.... Seriously people think major patches should drop once a day..... or small fixes... .No that's not how it works unless you got a gigantic dev team. even then it takes a few days for it to be fixed (Look at Early days of WOW)Thursdays/Fridays are a lottery of being 90% NERF DAY and 10% OP DAY..... The only thing I dislike about the game is no hero sortment.... but maybe that will come on later! since its an alpha (its been a alpha for a long time)

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
Please note: This is a first impressions review of the current pre-alpha build as of the 8th of December 2014. This is  NOT  an in-depth review and I'd just like to address my experience compared to other reviewers. Okay so, the first thing I want to address is the difficulty of the game. I've noticed a few reviewers talking about the difficulty of the game when it comes to playing solo. I myself enjoyed Dungeon Defenders 1 alone and rarely went online (partly due to the amount of hackers, but that's besides the point), so obviously I would be spending a vast majority of my time on this game offline or with a select group of friends, meaning if the game is much too hard for one person, I wouldn't be playing this game much at all, nor would I like it to be quite frank. However, as you can see, I've given this early access game a thumbs up. Why? Because it's not as hard in single player as others may believe. The entire game actually feels much easier overall compared to the original dungeon defenders.The mechanic that stands out as to why it's easier, is that  you no longer have to stand next to your towers and wait to repair or upgrade them.  While it's true you still need to be close to the towers to begin the process of repairing or upgrading them, you still move freely, and can carry on fighting enemies or go elsewhere on the map while it's repairing. A little bar on the side of your crosshair shows you the progress of the repair/upgrade so you're still conscious of your tower in the meantime. You can only upgrade or repair one tower at a time, like in the original dungeon defenders, but the fact you can no guard the tower yourself while it's repairing for example, ends up helping you in the longrun. Personally, this is a very welcome change to the core game as it feels like I'm now doing more than just running around the map repairing my towers; It's more of an incentive to fight yourself. Just to let any readers know, I've tried out all four of the heroes ALONE and had little trouble beating the first few maps with each of them WITHOUT grinding for experience to level up nor switching between heroes mid-game. I'll admit, the huntress is a little hard to play solo as she uses traps, but as they're so small and use little mana, you can place many of them around before filling out the max tower limit. The Monk is clearly made to play as part of a team seeing as it has health and tower boosts, but he can still very well stand his own ground alongside his defenses. Oddly enough, the Squire and the Apprentice felt very similar, as their first two towers are ranged projectile defenses and barricades. When playing as either of them, by the time I got to the final wave, I could (and did, to prove it to myself) sit back and watch as my towers did all the work. In my opinion, that doesn't make playing as them "easy", it just means I created a defense that was effective on the map.  Moving on, let me just say this game looks so much better than Dungeon Defenders 1. If you've seen the trailers or screenshots, as many of you have, you probably already know that. Besides the overall look and the new animations, it's just the little things I love most in games like this. On the first map, there's a tree with a squirrel on it, and sometimes it'll run down and jump on the fence posts and take a look around before running back up the tree. Things like that make the levels feel more unique and less hollow. Levelling up towers make them look drastically different, such as Squire's level 2 cannon getting taller and aining studs, or Apprentice's level 2 fireball shooter gaining eyes. This means you can know what level your tower is from a distance, just by looking at it, which is great for the fast-play action of this game.Bottom line, this game takes everything from Dungeon Defenders 1 and improves on it. Gameplay feels smoother/more inviting, the whole game looks better, the enemies are fiercer and even the Tavern is vastly improved (don't get me started on the item upgrader, I love what they've done with it). However... content-wise, there's not a lot of replayability right now besides finding weapons, changing the difficulty of the available maps and switching up characters, and that is literally the only reason why any self-respecting tower-defense fan should not have this game already, in it's current state. Final VerdictIf you're new to the Dungeon defenders franchise, then you should definitely go play the original game and wait for this game to become free-to-play. If you've played the original game, are a fan of the series, and want to help support the developers and watch this sequel go through it's development process, then you should get this game for sure, whether you want to play alone or with others. If I didn't know any better, I would never have believed this game would be free-to-play, as the quality here is much too good compared to most current games in the field.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDIT: Summoner is most busted character. His "towers" are really strong, as well as having one with pretty massive range, that shoots forwards and back, just set up a bunch of those around the objective and win alot. They also lost what made the summoner from DD1 special, which was that he turned the game into an rts style game. In DD2 the summoner might as well just be any other character.So far its ok, its not dungeon defenders 1 or anything, but its alright. Seeing as how its going to be free to play, I don't recommend paying for it unless you actually plan on influencing the game. I would much rather a game be a one time purchase and have a good game, rather then having in game shortcuts for real world money. They say they wont have anything in the shop that will effect the game, but I don't see that lasting long.Talking about the game now, the graphics got a major boost. Very pretty, and you don't need a massive build for your pc to play on max. The simplified skills and tower building is nice, as is the fact that upgrades are all one unified price.As far as the forseeable issues... Crafting has taken a massive hit in the quality department, you used to just put mana into an item and choose a stat to boost, and mana as a currency has been removed, its now just gold coins, which is kinda dumb, and instead of the innkeeper selling you a selection of 3 items, the innkeeper is who you report bugs to, and you buy armor from some guy, and your trinkets from some other guy... now to upgrade items you just combine things till you can make a stat SLIGHTLY better... its not really worth upgradeing gear till end game.Tl;Dr Its not as good as DD1, but will be worth playing when its free.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								council member here!DUNGEON DEFENDERS 2 REVEWWhen I bought the pre alpha trial, I was expecting some buggy, unfinished game, with a lack of textures, detailing and an overflow of bugs. What I found was a well-polished, very fun and exciting game to play, looking almost complete.Being a fan of the original DD, I was surprised by the very different style of graphics they used. The fantastic cartoon-like style was replaced by a more serious and realistic one. While it was criticized by lots of old players, I found this new look..... revigorating. Finally a company decides to end the old "don't change it if it's selling" and tries to change the way the game works.I found the maps VERY creative and fun to play, with some innovative and refreshing scenes, even for an experienced DD1 player to play. The graphics look very interesting and the new mechanics (such as the new carts and elements of the environment that help you clear the waves) are lots of fun to deal with.In my opinion the only things that aren't so good are the towers: trying to give them a new, realistic look ended up making some of them kind of lame (like the main knight tower), although the way they change looks when you upgrade them looks awesome.Overall, the game looks very very promising and if you are a fan of the DD1 and DD eternity you should definitely check this game- I give it 8,5/10

								It feels like this game is having an idenity crisis at times, DD2 was supposed to be a moba but they scrapped it. I am sure this game will come out great, but in its current state it feels lack luster (as expected from an early access game)So far, DD2 looks pretty nice. Great colors, great animations and fun towers and weapons to mess around with.

Early Access Review
								Fantastic game, certainly at this barely left alpha stage.The game is complete, you can enjoy everything with the occasional bug or glitch.Can the game be better? Offcourse it could be so much better, but let's remember they are still working on it.Can you compare the game to DD1? Partly, and that is what frustrates the DD1 players. You have to look at this as another game enterily.Can you play the game without spending real cash? yes you can enjoy everything playwise, you can buy costumes which cost tons of money. And with the carnival update you can "buy" older monthly pets, like bearkira. Why the quotes, well you buy tickets for the carnival game, and you have fixed rewards which include bearkira.Did I buy gems, yes, as I enjoyed the game very much and I want to support the creators.Do I hope the game evolves and get's better? Yes very much, and I'll be playing/following this game closely.Before this game I was an avid mmorpg lover, but all the mmorpg are just bland and boring.This is a mix between tower defense and rpg and I love that part as it keeps making to come back.I have high expectations for the game.So if you like tower defense games with a few rpg elements, this might be it.Enjoy it, as it is free

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I got this game once it became free, and it's brilliant. Like it's predecessor, DD2 does an excellent job of making a tower defense (one of the most boring game-types in my opinion) into a much more involved and fun experience. Everything from the original and more.However, it still has some problems that I assume the devs already know about and may or may not do anything about while still in EA. Some problems are...-Always Online. (From what I've seen) This is an idea that only works with MMORPGs and the AAA Multiplayer FPS's. A tower defense game that focuses on grinding (not a bad thing here) and has things in place for people that like to play solo is great, but Solo-players are forced to have a private session that's still connected to the internet. If your ISP decides to kill your connection or your wireless connection isâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ then you get kicked out of your private, SOLO match. It's not TERRIBLY awful, just a feature that shouldn't really be there.-Length of the Game so far. Not gonna lie to you, this game is grievously short. Yes, I know it's EA, it's gonna have more stuff, yadda yadda yadda; but it won't hold your attention too well after the campaign is over. After the story is done you essentially just screw around on the maps with tougher monsters at higher difficulties. -"Hard Difficulty" This is something alot of games honorably fail at. It's difficult to up the difficulty of something, sometimes it's simply made unfair (MGSV:PP, Iwannabetheguy, etc.) other times it's not that much harder or maybe it's easier (Legend of Zelda games, Metroid Prime, etc.). DD2 kinda flops in this regard as "Hard" mode is simply just aâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ton of enemies that hit harder. Sure, that makes it harder, but not by much. It would be nice to see a new mechanic introduced to make the challenge more of one. But what it should be, I dunno. Aside from the problems, this game is in EA, and it's free as far as I'm concerned. It's worth the look.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I personally have not played the first Dungeon Defenders game, but I put a ton of hours into Dungeon Defenders Eternity, and saying I enjoyed the experience is an understatement. For something in Pre-Alpha, the amount of development that has happened in this game is extremely exceptional. What you get out of the game depends on what you put into it, and to be perfectly honest, I feel like I have put a decent amount into it.Compared to Dungeon Defenders Eternity, this game offers a variety of ways to play, since one aspect I particular enjoy is the synergy that certain defenses can undergo with one another. To name a few, There is the Geyser/Storm Combo, which can keep certain targets in place (some argue the combo is broken, but I could not care less on that point), and another combo is something I call Magic Shatter (people may call it something else) where you freeze a target, then send it airborne. The result is when they come back down, the target shatters, most of the time instantly killing it. The point is unlike in DDE, The defenses all seem to have a particular place, and do not seem to make any single tower worthless. (except for maybe the Squire's Training Dummy)The gear in Dungeon Defenders 2 is already extremely versatile , with unique abilities to a certain item type that can greatly improve a player's performance, meanwhile in DDE, gear just improved tower and player stats directly. An example of some gear affixes are improving a specific tower performance, such as "Increased Flameburst Tower damage by 5.03%" making the item effectively an apprentice ideal item to improve his flameburst tower damage. This allows items to cater to specific classes, and once again improving the depth of the tower and also the character. There are some rarer mods that are extremely significant, so if you want to get truly powerful items, you have to be ready to hunt for them to get the best performance. Another thing I believe is improved compare to DDE is that gear is still able to be leveled, but leveling gear does not break the game as hard as it did in DDE. When you upgrade items, the stats will go up by a fixed amount every time, unlike in DDE, where the amount that the stat will increase is dependent on the stats the item had when it spawned.The next thing I will address is the leveling system. The leveling system itself is pretty straight forward, you get experience by completing waves and defeating enemies, as well as completing certain conditions to gain fixed experience points and gold. That is pretty standard, but it's a good system. The thing that I believe that DD2 has done amazingly is that instead of being able to allocate points to character and tower stats directly as a result of leveling up, the character and tower stats go up automatically, and once you reach level 5, you gain 2 points that you can put into passive skills to improve your characters performance in a series of ways. For example, the Squire is able to place points into an ability that gives his spike barricades a chance to stun enemies when they attack targets. The more points you put into a skill, the more effective it becomes. As you put more points in, the results will have diminishing returns, so a player can decide when enough is enough, and begin skilling other abilities. Furthermore, you can completely respec your skills for free at any time, so long as you are not in the middle of a wave, allowing you to test out various builds and find a setup that suits you. Each character has 6 skills you can invest in.The next thing I will address is the enemies. A few of the classic enemies make their return, goblins, orcs, wyverns, etc. The enemies still come from a variety of spawn points, where a variety of enemies will come out of each one. Those enemies were great in DDE, and most of them return in DD2. The enemy cast also expands, offering new challenges to overcome. One particular subject that has received mixed criticism is that some enemies have the ability to attack towers from outside of the common tower's attack ranges. This makes the game a bit more of a puzzle, due to the fact that unlike in DDE, tower ranges can't be increased to such an obscene level to counter absolutely everything that the map may throw at you. This does not break the game, there are still measures that the player can take to manage the various enemies, both old and new.The final subject I will touch on is the Co-op play. I never went to public taverns and went looking for people to play with, so I won't comment too much on public matchmaking, but I have friends I have played with, and this game is just as awesome in Co-op as it is in solo play. If you have friends that you know and can communicate with, the experience is far more satisfying. The enemies will scale with the number of party numbers, both in health and overall difficulty, making it a perfect game to either play solo, or bring in some of your friends to go beat down the Old One's armies.To conclude, for a game in its Pre-Alpha state, I believe this game is exceptional, and will go far. The devs are working to update the game, listening to feedback, and working to balance the game. Some things in the game still need fixing, some things still need to be balanced, but the game is still very young, and I am certain it will develop into a memorable classic. It will turn into a F2P at launch, but to be perfectly honest, I don't mind having paid for the game. I'm actually glad to have paid, because it's a way people can say "thank you" to the creators, especially since the game will be free at launch unless something changes that. In a nutshell, if you enjoyed the first Dungeon Defenders, I would assume you would enjoy DD2, the same holds true for Dungeon Defenders Eternity.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Super good looking game, looks 10x better than the previous games.What i loved in the first DD is that you could make your build as leader, then you could be afk (as an option). I go for 20-30min and come back, wether im just waiting solo or actually letting the towers do their thing while im afk.It makes sense that party members get disconnected, because otherwise everyone could just be afk but the leader should have that option, especially if you're solo.Otherwise im obligated to finish and i cant possibly be afk, otherwise my build and games is ruined. (Lets say i wanted to take a break from Survival, when that comes).And doesn't that also mean that the party members that join will disconnect too ?At least thats how it was in the DD1..I think DDII will get a lot better, most of things people are babbling about being able to join games, making partys, the interface, inventory, skill points etc - Those things will get upgraded and fixed, that is pretty obvious.Im just concerned about the disconnecting and being able to enjoy the gameplay as of this moment.But once that happens i will be the one spenting countless hours in this game and buying every DLC like in DDI.Also the DDII team is amazing, they update/fix all the time and listen to every opinions they can and are always looking to improve.That makes me buy their games right away, even if its a bad one like Eternity, dont really care.Update: Love the new updates, amazing new features. Love the staff.They also support kids in need that have nothing.Highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I got so much loot that I no longer care about loot.  I'm dead inside now... This game is in early alpha and is already better than many games I've played.  No game breaking bugs, no strange occurrences, no texture/mesh issues (at least ones that can't be blamed on my spotty internet) and it's fun!  The only major issue I've seen is it has some balance issues.  However, those issues are in your favor so it's not frustrating.  Dungeon Defenders II is exactly like the previous title, except free.  You play as one of four heros to build towers and defenses to make sure your (usually) crystal is spared from getting destroyed by invading monsters who want it for reasons not totally mentioned (early alpha).  You can build said character however you see fit.  Want them to be a wall of defense while your friends fry, electrify, and explode them?  Would you rather take things into your own hands or let your towers do the work?  Slice them?  Shoot them?  Or...uh...magic them?  You can do this solo but it's more fun with other players.  I'd imagine it's even more fun if you play with friends and can communicate with your talking.  It's also probably easier.  There's quite a few levels to play, and all look amazing.  Each level has it's own spawning routes and challenges.  Sadly, the monsters never change so it might get boring killing the same goblins and orcs over and over and over again.  The good news is, they often die before you get a good look at them.  As I said earlier, this game has balance issues.  Enemies die, maybe, too quickly for the games own good.  Right now, it might get boring.  The developers try to alleviate this by adding excursion modes with increase the difficulty but a good party of four can still find it a push-over.  Right now, though, I think the devs have other things on their mind and to do list than increase the difficulty.  I'm sure that'll happen later on as the game gets pushed to an official release.  Either that or archers are OP!  For now, enjoy the slaughter of your enemies and dance in their dropped blue mana crystals!  There's still the issues with having way too much equipment drops from mobs but I believe there was an auto-sale option in the first one so I'm sure the sequel will have it in time, as well.

								I've been playing the game since early in pre-alpha.  I have almost 800hrs played.  That amount of time invested in this game speaks for itself.  The game is great, as well as the development team.  They continually look for feedback from the playerbase which continues to grow.  Anyone interested in tower defense, action RPG, or loot based games will find something to love about this game.  There is loads of customization both in gameplay as well as character appearances.  The game has now gone free2play, so I think there are no excuses not to give this game a go.  New content and patches have kept the game fresh and I always look forward to seeing how the game evolves.  Keep up the great work Trendy.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been playing the game since early in pre-alpha.  I have almost 800hrs played.  That amount of time invested in this game speaks for itself.  The game is great, as well as the development team.  They continually look for feedback from the playerbase which continues to grow.  Anyone interested in tower defense, action RPG, or loot based games will find something to love about this game.  There is loads of customization both in gameplay as well as character appearances.  The game has now gone free2play, so I think there are no excuses not to give this game a go.  New content and patches have kept the game fresh and I always look forward to seeing how the game evolves.  Keep up the great work Trendy.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hi,this is my first Review on a Game ever on Steam and I post it because I care about the future of this game. Many recent Reviews are posted because of a company lawsuite and not because they really played the game (Game played 0-2h is not really worth giving a Review and its shady that they can...). I just don't want the game to become a rating "mixed" or "not positiv" because of a company decision rather than on reviewing the game itself...I enjoyed playing in the past and I will play it again in April, when the next big patch hits the game.It is a good successor of DD1 and I really enjoyed playing DD1 too. It is free to play and you can't pay 2 win your way through it. It gets updated on a regular basis and with the April patch it will leap some more steps towards the direction of a worthy successor of DD1.Happy gaming.Fuelli

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders is a game where you build towers and upgrades, to defend your castle from incoming invading monsters. During the game you will get a lot of loot, to upgrade your character and defences, to defend the castle some more.It is similar to Dungeon Defenders 1, but with new and shiny graphics.If you like DD1, you will also like DD2.Note that currently (3-1-2015) the game is in pre-alpha and needs a few tweaks here and there, but overall it's a nice refresh of the Dungeon defender saga.Graphics: 7 out of 10Sound: 7 out of 10Gameplay: 8 out of 10Replayability: 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played some 500+ hours in DD1, and while that isn't a ton of time, I'd like to think that I am a fan of the games. I've only played upwards of 25 hours in DD2 and to be honest, I couldn't be more pleased so far. That said, judging this game now would be ridiculous, it's in PRE-ALPHA, which translate to this not finished game, they will add more things and the game will continue to improve. So just wait a bit, taking a pre-alpha game at face value would be silly. So a word of advice from a random gamer, if you're on the fence about this game wait until it's released to give it a chance. Pros of the game:-Great graphics-More levels-New enemy types/ bosses-New abilities-Specs-The Squire found pants. The cons:-Must be online to play. Who knows though, that may change. -Some of the spec options are "Meh" at best. -You're unable to out level an area, If I'm 16 in a 10-15 zone, I'm scaled down as to not over power the level. -Increasing the range of your defences can be a pain as it is not a stat, you find it on gear. All in all this is a wonderful foundation for a game, As they add more into the game, I'm sure it will continue improve and it will be a worthy successor to DD1. As for now, it's one hell of a fun game.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Sadly the second installment on this series does not capture the spirit of the first game.Gone are the days of going from zero to hero and slicing through waves of enemies. What has replaced it is a grindfest of the dull, stale and tedious kind that embodies modern free-to-play games.I still have hopes that the devs will turn things around as there is potential in the game but there has been more focus on costumes (sound more expensive than AAA titles) and other trivia instead of fixing the currently broken mechanics.Go play the original until this game has matured or died.

Early Access Review
								This is still my Favorite game but it needs local play.The problem is, with the first Dungeon Defenders you could play private matches without rubberbanding around the whole map.The online play isn't bad but considering there are only a select few servers available at the moment, I'd say wait until they are done developing (it's in Alpha now) and play it when the local play is made available.Unless your in EU (Frankfort) , Asia Pacific (Singapore), US East (Northen Virginia) or close surounding  areas you are probably going to experience some kind of latency.All in all this game is meant to be played online at all times, but it'd be nice if they could get to Dungeon defenders 1's level of completion.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok so I have played around 3 hours of this game so far and I am confident on this review now. Pros of the game:- Amazing atmosphere- No pay to win stores- No "head start" packs- Great graphics- Amazing community of people to play with- Fun with friends- Decently optimised for a pre-alpha game- Loads of story missions to complete as well as daily missions- No frame drops on MOST maps- Great class selectionsCons:- Server can be choppy at times- Fell under the map a bunch- General audio glitches (rare when it happens)Final thoughts:This game is getting a 10/10 for me, it is a fun game to play and was done well. I am glad they made it F2P during the testing of the game and I hope they keep it F2P after the full release. You should all download this game now as it is a fun as hell tower defence game at it's finest AND IT'S STILL IN PRE-ALPHA SO IMAGINE WHEN IT GETS A FULL RELEASE :D

content:

Early Access Review
								After playing dungeon defenders 1 for a couple hundred hours or so, i was very saatisfied with the game it was. I enjoyed the combat, the towers, and the aspects of each map.After playing 3 maps from dungeon defenders 2, i have learned that the combat has more depth to it, the towers are much more interesting(especially upgrading them) and the map aspects are better as well. The character upgrading also has been upgraded tremendiously. With a much more polished feel and still in alpha i am excited to see what the game has to offer as i level up.So far i am thoroughly impressed, and although i haven't gotten into the more complicated aspects of the game i am willing to say i know it is a beautiful second version of an already amazing game!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Despite this being early access, it feels very well polished. If you enjoyed the first game, this will feel very natural to get back in to, It feels very similar in a good way! A lot better looking and with a lot more depth from the looks of what is already in the game at this point.There are a few niggles however, the game will be coming out on a Free to Play model at release so if you can hold out that long you get it for free. This also means pay to play elements will be added. Hopefully this wont mean pay to win, but we'll have to wait and see. By buying into the game now you are granted some of the pay to play currency for free, in the future when those elements are added, as well as a few exclusive items/skins. So it's kind of paying forward some pay to play items, by buying it now.Also, it is always online, which for me isnt an issue but is a bit of a bummer for some. It also seems to have an odd lobby/session system which feels like theres an unnecessary step in there. But this is a minor problem really.Overall, if you see yourself playing this game a lot, and enjoyed the first, i'd say its worth getting now. If you're on the fence, maybe wait until the f2p release.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played the original Dungeon Defenders on the Xbox 360 and it was very fun to play with friends.  I got Dungeon Defenders 2 on steam for early access before it was free to play.  Great game with hours upon hours of content, level progression, loot collection, and a plethora of other things that make Dungeon Defenders 2 such an intriguing game.  Hard to actually explain the game, sort of a castle defense but with so much more replay value; play the game to find out for yourself!  Runs great for an early access game.  I have tested it on two other systems, an older one with an FX 4100 and HD7850 2GB, and a very powerful system with an i7 6700k and a GTX 970.  It ran pretty bad on the older one and wasnât even able to keep a stable 60fps on a combination of settings.  On the i7 6700k and GTX 970 it runs amazing, average of over 100fps with everything completely maxed.  Oddly enough it runs at that framerate while only utilizing half of the GPU's power so not sure if they will fix it or if it is some restriction of the engine.  Overall great, fun, and addictive game.  Download it.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok so I have played around 3 hours of this game so far and I am confident on this review now. Pros of the game:- Amazing atmosphere- No pay to win stores- No "head start" packs- Great graphics- Amazing community of people to play with- Fun with friends- Decently optimised for a pre-alpha game- Loads of story missions to complete as well as daily missions- No frame drops on MOST maps- Great class selectionsCons:- Server can be choppy at times- Fell under the map a bunch- General audio glitches (rare when it happens)Final thoughts:This game is getting a 10/10 for me, it is a fun game to play and was done well. I am glad they made it F2P during the testing of the game and I hope they keep it F2P after the full release. You should all download this game now as it is a fun as hell tower defence game at it's finest AND IT'S STILL IN PRE-ALPHA SO IMAGINE WHEN IT GETS A FULL RELEASE :D

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is really fun, especially if you have friends who'd also get this. If you don't have friends, there's a matchmaker too! Reviewing this in early access, there was a bug where units would spawn and block each other on their pathway leading into battle, not allowing anybody to hit them. After a few minutes, they gradually freed themselves except for the last unit, who died standing there. At least it doesn't break the game, and it's only happened once. The game is loads of fun, and I highly recommend it while on sale in its current state. There's still more that needs to be done, but it's definitely at least a fun, playable game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
Early Access Review
								I loved the first game and was excited to try this with some of my friends who weren't able to pick up the original.The two of us that had played DD1 were immediately offput by the less-intuitive and unexplained changes to loot and mana, as well as the extremely clunky UI and default keybinds, especially as compared to the first game. We also had a sense that some towers were virtually useless, compared to the original in which everything had at least one good purpose.All four of us were disheartened seeing the price of new characters (10k tokens) compared to token gain (4-5 per map in the beginning, some reading told us 25 is a high amount later on, plus 100-300 for dailies and a few thousand for monthlies).We were surprised to fail the fifth level, having one of each starter character across the four players. Upgraded walls were dying in half a wave, and our resources were spread thin due to sprawling map design and two spread-out defense points. None of us could discern enemy paths before they were shown to us.Inventory and gear management were beyond nightmarish. There was no sorting that we could find, so items got lost a lot. Comparisons are fine most of the time, but totems/medallions/orbs/whatever seem to compare to a random equipped one but always replace the one in the first slot. Shards took a while to figure out.In general nothing is explained except the very obvious basic controls.From what I've heard a lot of this is due to a recent patch, but in the current state I cannot recommend the game as a game, at least to new players. It may be fine to certain groups of friends who are wanting the challenge or who don't really care much about playing the game in a way that makes sense, I guess.Overall I would have put DD1 as an 8/10 overall and a 10/10 for its genre. I'd put DD2 as a 6.5/10 for the genre and a 3.5/10 overall.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								My thoughts of the game so far.Pros-Better combat systembetter towersBigger tavernBetter graphicsBetter player level systemCons-Key layoutCashshopclass slots cost real moneyTavern setup its everyone in one tavernBigger bag cost real moneycostumes cost real moneyloot boxes cost real money to unlockNo trading systemYes i get with a f2p game they need money in order to keep the game going such as every thing costing real money to get. I think if they added things from first game it could be alot better. I don't like haven't buy class slots or costumes. In dungeon defenders one they gave you 12+ class slots all free you didnt have to buy any thing with real money but big dlcs with came with hoilday quest, more story mission more items, costumes, challanges and the most was 20 dollars. I just feel like they are missing some of the best from from the other two games.Its not all bad they have improved alot of things but with some of the best stuff missing from the other games. They also took out offline so you must have internet to play. There is also a lack of towers from the first game, now when i say that what i mean is they took out some of the towers from the first game wich i don't know why all towers were used and needed for the first one.DLC: parts from the first game was you did have to buy it but as i said before it came with alot of added stuff. Now if you want somthing that looks cool you have to buy gems (real money) . In the first one in order to get cool costumes, weapons or even pets you had to beat a challange or a level on normally a high difficulty. I feel from that there was some pride when you get it cause it shows you went through alot to get it. Now you can just buy it me personally i would rather earn it.Tavern: I liked the way that had it setup where you there was a list of matches. So you can see all the matches being played. You could host your own tavern. But with that there are pros and cons from that like from people hosting there own matches they could kick you if they wanted but with that its also good for it people arent helping or causing problems. Also with having taverns you could set out the items you've gotten from your troubles of hard work for trades like if you're looking for a weapon but cant get you could trade for it with money, weapons, armor and even pets. Also i just remembered that the trophies you unlocked were setup in the tavern to show what you've completed. That helps people know if you can help them with a challange or with a very challanging match.Class slots: They only give you 4 class slots which i think is **** compared to what they had in the first one 12+ class slots Which allowed you to make  tower and dps classes instead of one or the other but with that being said in the first one they did have more classes to choose from instead of the base four. THIS REVIEW WILL BE CHANGED AND UPDATED THE MORE I PLAY THE GAME AND IT GETS UPDATE CHANGES TO THE GAME.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is probably one of the only games capable of going toe to toe with dark souls for entertainment sake.Dark souls for me made all other games pretty much obsolete because they where ever too easy or just have no interesting content for me to explore and build upon.Dunged Defenders II is a fun and very addicting experience it will keep your attention for the best of two weeks because there is always that chance of finding a better bow or getting those leggings that you have been looking for this whole time.The difficulty is more like a progress checker I kept going back to the first level on a even higher difficulty to see if I was ready to take on that harder challenge that would destroy me everytime.There are three modes other then Campaign there is Free play, incursion and onslaught:Free play was fun to play after I had beaten the campaign because it was like all the enemies that I had come across in the campaign all came to gether in the earlier maps to test my ability to adapted to a new situation and there was a harder difficulty that was unlocked to make me strive to become stronger. Then there is incursion mode this was an nice twist on older maps that I had previously played Because there was different concept on every map that made it interesting to see how it would playout in the end.And finally but not least there was the onslaught mode now that was the mode to test how strong you were and to get better gear like you never though possible, You would face pretty much an endless horde of enemies that would test your ability to set up defences and maintain them for as long as possible before the inevitability that the enemies would burst though you lines ending the game.But when I though I had done everything on the hardest difficulty I found there was a rude awaking that there was a mode called endgame that made the game take on a whole new light. Only by beating the game and getting to Lv40 could you play this mode and what it did was bring all the previous game modes and allowed you to play on a difficulty's called nightmare 1, 2, 3 & 4 and like the name suggest its like a nightmare.That's when I reached out to people in the community to help me and they were all to happy to help push me into the verge that was nightmare difficulty, Now i am onto nightmare 4 and still can't seem to get enough without saying to my self just one more game.

								I'm rating this game as a no. I have had multiple problems with it on launch. It will freeze, stop working, then tell me that it's missing a bunch of files. Most of these files are in the binaries. Until they patch this game, I won't be able to play it anymore. In order to get into it initially, I had to go through the steam store website. I was then able to play the game. I think it's a fun game, for the total of 1 hour that I played it. I then logged out. I haven't been able to get back in since. I know it's not a problem with steam, as all of my other games work perfectly. I tried disabling my firewall and letting it reinstall. That didn't work. I tried the various different .exe files, and that didn't work. I verified all the files installed, and that did nothing. My computer is very capable of handling this game. If they patch the update, and it works, I will happily rewrite this review. Until then 0/10. Oh and yes I realize this is just the alpha, but no I will not change the score because of that. If I did, then it would mean that making a game with this many start problems is okay, and it is not.0/10 upon first review.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like dungeon defenders 1, then this game would seem like a good buy, it has a lot of aspects like the last game but they have added a bunch ofâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥that makes it unplayableMicro transactions for: Character slots, skins, weapons, gold, missions, and any stat reset. there is no earning anything in this game. you might as well be playing this on a phone because with all these micro transactions it should be one.Nothing New- Same classes. same idea.UI and Item ID's - The way they show you items on the ground and the 6 stats all the items have cause you to have to look over them twice as much before knowing if it is really a stat increase or just an attack speed buff. The UI is also really cluttered, like... not much thought or time was put in to make this thing pretty or non-invasive over the game.Honestly I was really excited for this game; I bought it as a loyal customer of the original game but ended up being disappointed over and over. Some levels are so easy that you can throw them on hard and grind to over level the rest of the game. This game is sadly nothing like the 1st and they decided to sell out to micro transactions to cash out on this as fast as possible.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Grew up with TDs in Wc3, love playing this type of game as it really chills me out. This game reminds me more of the hero line wars than an actual TD which is great imo, as much as I like to afk as I plant my towers down (you still can if you want) I like how now hero damage builds actually work and can really speed up maps, when i first played this game a year ago the builder way was pretty much the only way, hero damage builds were kind of a joke. All in all I am very pleased with returning to this game but I can see how people are concerned how relativly easy it is to aquire great gear with the carnaval wheel. I returned to DD2 exactly a week ago and am currently in NM 4  with 4 lvl 50s with IPWR 580 after 70 hours of solo play, for me it is still very enjoyable as I still have 120 more IPWR to go for and with the release of a patch with a new hero (and map?) tomorrow I am very stoked. Another very cool thing that is coming is that they will sortoff unlock your hero deck where all your active heroes can be in the deck but you can use all the heroes you own to build, meaning that as they release more heroes, the combinations will be endless... specially benificial for us solo players.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II is easily, hands down, my second favorite game EVER, only being bested by Dungeon Defenders I. I'm not going to be that guy that says Dungeon Defenders II is a bad game because it isn't as good as the first game of the series, as Dungeon Defenders II is still in development, meaning it will get new story, characters, mechanics, and become a better game over all. So, to the point, I definately recommend this game, and for a couple reasons too.1) Loot, loot, and more loot. I personally LOVE loot mechanics to games, even just looking at an items stats and comparing it to another item in every single way.2) This game is fun to play by your self, and playing with your friends, I've played this game mostly by my self, as most of my friends weren't too into the game, which was kind of disapointing, but I've been having fun with this game by my self ever since.I would give a con list of sorts, but I honestly can't think of anything bad about the game.So overall 11/10, would let my friends ditch me to play COD Black Ops III again.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This isn't the main game that I play, usually I just jump on this game with friends to have some fun and relax.With that in mind, the most important part for this game is the developer involvement:DEVSTREAMS: Every week the developers stream for an hour. The stream has gameplay in the background, a camera that has two developers answering questions from the chat and forums, and another camera with a game developer working on game assets (designing weapons or making animations).DEVLOGS: These are a bit more informal and usually just a sentence or two. But every developer posts what they have been working on that week. At the very least it lets you know what is coming up soon.INFLUENCE VOTES: For logging into the game (and the forums) you can get influnce points, then the team has public votes for different systems that the community prefers (how loot drops work, how to acquire certain items, etc). So you can just save up your points and actually make quite a considerable difference in something you feel strongly about.All of this in addition to other videos for events and whatnot featuring developers answering questions on the forums or emails. They also have a department dedicated to going through every bug report sent through the in game system, the game is going to be in early access for quite a while, so it is nice to be able to follow along.The game has bugs and isn't too terribly rich in the content department right now, but it's still pretty early in development.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								No one agrees with my reviews, but I still make em. :DNov 2016 edit: And hey! Look at that slowly collapsing playerbase. Love to shove it in all the naysayers faces and told ya so. You know your game is poor when you make a free to play sequel and there are still a measurable amount playing the first. Like a third relatively speaking. BTW the game is STILL in early access...+Attractive cartoony characters and great aesthetic visual style.+Levels are pretty nice to look at and are fairly well designed.+Controls work quite well.+Abilities and towers have some synergy.+Some talents are pretty cool.+Some weapons are goofy in a good way such as 'book on a stick' that fires pages. (This fits in with the aesthetic pretty well.)+Cute pets.+Sub objectives to protect help to shape the pathing of enemies.+Stage traps that work.+Stats were made more complex.+Free to play!+Huntress is a hottie!-Glitchy/buggy. Just starting the game up and trying to switch settings around I crashed a couple times and http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/395551484001360154/C97977F6DA79498412EF112ACECC4D8C5D1E68E3/ happened which forced me to restart again. It worked after fiddling quite a bit, but it was never quite this bad.-Random framerate drops. The game used to run smoothly, but seems to struggle now for some reason even in just the lobby.-Microtransactions in early access and already priority has shifted to making more over new content: 


Yes look at all these god damn microtransaction. Look at them all! The game isn't even out of early access...Â 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders II
By: Milan Mree Frozen




-No recoloring. (This may not be big for others, but it is big for me.)-Extremely grindy.-You can only level 1 char at a time even though you can bring up to four after unlocking them all meaning you are only leveling 1 char and you will need to level them all if you want to play alone meaning MORE GRIND.-Level synching makes power leveling non existant meaning you will have to grind even more. (part of me wants to like this, but the fact you have to grind four people makes this a no no.)-Playing solo is very difficult and requires you to play even longer for any chance.-Stage traps are often inconvenient to activate, too difficult to activate, in a bad position to build walls or the timing is garbage on them.-The sub objectives in later levels don't seem to be too important especially in the ramparts where putting all your towers in a central location draws better, faster and more effecient results. They are a gimmick, one that is poorly thought out.-Playing with others is not a great experience. I know I am no saint, I am not a great person, but the community here puts my rage and general poor socialization to shame. Don't believe me, go right on ahead and try the game out.-Talents are locked behind gold walls forcing you to spend lots of gold to unlock them.-Gear and combos are too heavily emphasized. (Huntress water trap + monk aura is in almost every game.)-Minimal strategy involved. (You will set up your stuff the same almost every time simply because of the aformentioned combo and gear emphasis and magic/physical resistant enemies become pointless later on because you will NEED this setup regardless to progress.)-AI is very poor. Some enemies will get stuck, others will just not work: 


Dungeon Defenders IIÂ 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders II
By: Milan Mree Frozen




  (The enemy sees my towers below and begins throwing his spear into the wall repeatedly. This is not the only time it has happened and it is easily replicatable trivializing certain encounters.)-Only four playable with four abilities (one of which is heal on everyone) and four towers means there really isn't that much variety.-Pets are a chore to level and just add more grind.-Not everyone knew this game would be F2P and not everyone is happy that it went F2P. (I wouldn't have paid a dime to play this game if I could've)-Inventory space is limited. There is an auto loot system in place where you can specify what loot goes where, but the problem is that if you have it on auto loot and you run out of space and you 'auto loot' something you want, it just goes bye bye. You can specify item rarity, but this is still a huge flaw as it CAN happen. There used to be a system in place that would take all items you left on the ground and put them in a temp chest, but for some reason they removed that (and there was no initiative vote for it.)-Initiave votes are a joke and have no real effect on the game. See: https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/11 Players have no real effect on the game with the votes. You are not changing anything or affecting anything as is evidenced by these joke of a votes. Here's another : https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/19  Oh boy choose the COLOR. So stupid. (I am pretty sure the numbers on them are skewed as well.)-Because the game is 'tower defense' it has little to no variety and the only boss in the game is just plain tedious to fight and the mechanic they do is place a 'curse' down making you have to move your towers/traps. That would be fun and such except the placement is random and it will occassionally cause your buildings to be 'cut off' from some pathing. I do not have an example unfortunately, but the idea is that so much of a path is cursed that you can't protect it sufficiently enough. Especially if you play solo.-very VERY little content. I went on a 4-6 month hiatus from this game and came back and there was LITERALLY NO NEW CONTENT. Just more skins. I can't believe this is acceptable for a game at any point.-There is no huntress skin where the progressive unlocks give her bigger boobs and a curvier body or the more mana she has she is curvier. (And why isn't there huh? If you're not going to put the succubus in the game at least give the huntress some more up top. Sheesh.)Look, it's free to play. Great. Should you try it? Sure why not? If you got time to spare yeah. For me I don't have time to spare. I would rather pay money for a great experience than none for a bare bones, no content experience that I don't even enjoy. If they had put it on the main page in big bold letters (THIS GAME WILL BE FREE TO PLAY AT SOME POINT) Then I would have no excuse to be upset, but money was spent on it so I am upset. Very very very little that I would want of this game came true so I am not recommending you play it or support the devs. That's it. Have a great day.TLDR - Beautiful aesthetic, good controls, great concept, way too grindy and NO CONTENT.
