content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								For a game that is f2p and in alpha im quite impressed by the result.DD2 is a very casual Tower Def game that suits players of all age.Theres a decent amount of dif maps to be played with each of them having a few tricks to make them easier.The game includes 4 dif heroes to choose from - pets - equipment (not only +stat) and a lot of grind. My only real problem with the game is that it's way too easy to reach the highest difficulty nm4. And progressing through the difficulties is based on getting new gear from harder maps - which drives people to join games that are too difficult for them, so that they can be carried by the others a few times to up their gear. Progressing from nm3 to nm4 and from nm4 900 to 1000 just requires getting carried once through a map to get usable gear.After a player has reached the highest possible difficulty, thats when the real grind starts. Getting the optimal gear will take a lot of time and you end up running the same map over and over. The real issue with the game is the fact that progressing doesn't feel very rewarding. You can easily grind a lvl 1 hero to 50 in 2 hours if you know what you are doing and reach the top difficulty in a day.Theres no real character customisation in the game. Sure theres stat points that lead to certain builds, but the builds are so obvious and 1 way streets that everyone ends up with the same builds. Until nm4 you can defeat the maps with a big variety of strategies, but after you reach the highest difficulty, theres 1 strategy that you might have to tweak a bit depending on the map.The game also has some weird fps drop problems for me during the first 15-20 minutes, after which they completely disappear.Over all the game is a good time sink and decently fun - but the game feels too simple and easily beaten that I wouldn't for that reason invest any money on this. After playing 34 hours I can already say that im bored of running nm4 incursion  and nm4 necro and that theres no real replay value here. The game is just very repeatative and doesn't give me the feel of real progression or uniqueness to my character.My suggestion would be to take a look at the stat point system really well and ask if theres something to be changed there. I would also want to see some type of real customisation on your hero - skill points + skill tree (for towers etc.) to choose from?I understand there ideas would make balancing difficult and would require the devs to create a lot new skills with real variety, but something needs to be done to make the game more interesting.I up voted this game, but if there was a neutral option I would have gone for that.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II is easily, hands down, my second favorite game EVER, only being bested by Dungeon Defenders I. I'm not going to be that guy that says Dungeon Defenders II is a bad game because it isn't as good as the first game of the series, as Dungeon Defenders II is still in development, meaning it will get new story, characters, mechanics, and become a better game over all. So, to the point, I definately recommend this game, and for a couple reasons too.1) Loot, loot, and more loot. I personally LOVE loot mechanics to games, even just looking at an items stats and comparing it to another item in every single way.2) This game is fun to play by your self, and playing with your friends, I've played this game mostly by my self, as most of my friends weren't too into the game, which was kind of disapointing, but I've been having fun with this game by my self ever since.I would give a con list of sorts, but I honestly can't think of anything bad about the game.So overall 11/10, would let my friends ditch me to play COD Black Ops III again.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: If you loved the first one, you'll at least like this one. If you haven't played the first one, I'd recommend you to do that. But if you don't have the money, this is a great alternative. Let me start off by saying DD1 is one of my favorite games of all time. Therefore this review may be a bit biased. For a game in alpha stage it's definitely not bad, there is a decent amount of content and more is being developed all the time. I bought the game more or less as soon as it was available and I don't regret that decision. You could get it for free, and here's why you should:Even if you've played DD1, it feels like a new game. It's different enough, but at the same time it's similar enough to be called a Dungeon Defenders game. Leveling feels somewhat rewarding, though the early levels go by really fast while the later levels are a grind. However, it's rather satisfying to hit that level you needed for a new weapon or piece of armor.Extremely fun with friends. If you're playing this alone or with randoms, you're missing out.The graphics are beautiful. A definite upgrade from DD1The map designs are great, the only complaint here is that some maps in DD1 felt bigger. Trendy communicates with the playerbase, frequent devstreams and posts. This is something you don't see very often, especially this early in development. Some of the weapons have really cool passive effects. There's a lot of variety in weapons, especially bows. You could find 4 of the same bow and they could all have a different shot types, making them better for different situations.One of my biggest complaints is a bit of an odd one. I really don't like the fact that it's f2p. Maybe it's the fear of it becoming p2w, but I highly doubt that will happen. Another thing is the amount of paid DLC's. DD1 had a TON of them, and the game wasn't free. Now that this one is free, it feels like there will be even more DLC's. I don't mind throwing a bit of cash at the game however, but I really hope the amount won't be excessive. Most of the negative things I have to say about the game will (probably) be fixed by the time the game fully releases, so I won't get too much into them but:Upgrading weapons isn't that rewarding. There aren't as many upgrade levels on weapons, probably partly due to how they changed the upgrading system as a whole. You can only have so many items to upgrade with. The amount of legendary drops you get. In DD1 this wasn't as much of a problem. Now it's rare to go even one map without getting a legendary. It doesn't feel satisfying at all, and most of the time they're worse than the equipment you're already using anyway. They are nice for upgrading other gear though.The towers feel a bit more.. bland? compared to DD1. Though I do really like how you can change certain towers (or abilities) with uber spheres. The lack of challenge mode. I can't remember exactly what it was called but if you've played DD1 you probably know what I'm talking about.I enjoyed showing off my achievements in DD1 inside my tavern, especially with the eternia crystal. There aren't that many achievements in the game yet, but when they do add them I hope we'll get something like that. I find it kind of silly how they're already about to release an additional hero, when in DD1 it took them almost 2 years. I don't mind a new hero to play around with, but I'd prefer some other content instead. This review probably wasn't very coherent at all, but the point I'm trying to make is that the game is worth a try, especially with the $0 price tag. I have faith in Trendy, the game will improve by heaps by the time of release.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've tried to time after time enjoy this sequal to Dungeon Defenders, a game which I put well over 300 hours into, but I simply cannot seem to find that same spark that the first Dungeon Defenders had. The game has been in Alpha for well over 2 years and in that time the developer seem to have seemingly forgotten about what actually made Dungeon Defenders such an enjoyable game. And instead opted to try and get as much money out of their fans. Just look at the DLC's available, 135â¬ worth of DLC's for a game that is supposedly in Early Access Alpha. This without mentioning the in-game cash shop currency which is essentially needed to get even a remotely decent experience. All this while the game still runs like garbage.In the end if you are interested in the Dungeon Defenders concept simply grab the original Dungeon Defenders. It will give you a much better experience overall.

Early Access Review
								this game is semi fun to play, it's still in early release, and thus not a finished product.There are constant changes and the devs are always adding things to it. At the moment if writing this review they are adding EVE2.0 into the game, whom you can earn by completing daily missions (6-10 tokens per mission once a day plus a monthly mission i have NEVER been close to finishing) Eve is 10k tokens, Or you can buy for RealMoney.....the tokens are also used to buy spheres that change your abilities or buy keys that unlock costumes. I dont like the fact that the game is FULL of micro transactions and you cannot play the new features without buying stuff for RealMoney, the last example was a carneval map that you had to buy a ticket for to play.When I bought this game it was not a free to play game, so when it did turn that way and i saw the amount of time that went into designing new costumes and maps you could only get if you paid more money for it made me somewhat bitter. I have a bunch of max level characters, and i will ocasionally log in and play with my wife, we play a few maps and then get bored. We arent powerful enough for the nightmare mode but the gear that drops 1 difficulty lower is usually 10 levels below our level so it's near impossible to get upgrades. id say this is 4/10.

This is not the only time it has happened and it is easily replicatable trivializing certain encounters.)-Only four playable with four abilities (one of which is heal on everyone) and four towers means there really isn't that much variety.-Pets are a chore to level and just add more grind.-Not everyone knew this game would be F2P and not everyone is happy that it went F2P. (I wouldn't have paid a dime to play this game if I could've)-Inventory space is limited. There is an auto loot system in place where you can specify what loot goes where, but the problem is that if you have it on auto loot and you run out of space and you 'auto loot' something you want, it just goes bye bye. You can specify item rarity, but this is still a huge flaw as it CAN happen. There used to be a system in place that would take all items you left on the ground and put them in a temp chest, but for some reason they removed that (and there was no initiative vote for it.)-Initiave votes are a joke and have no real effect on the game. See: https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/11 Players have no real effect on the game with the votes. You are not changing anything or affecting anything as is evidenced by these joke of a votes. Here's another : https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/19  Oh boy choose the COLOR. So stupid. (I am pretty sure the numbers on them are skewed as well.)-Because the game is 'tower defense' it has little to no variety and the only boss in the game is just plain tedious to fight and the mechanic they do is place a 'curse' down making you have to move your towers/traps. That would be fun and such except the placement is random and it will occassionally cause your buildings to be 'cut off' from some pathing. I do not have an example unfortunately, but the idea is that so much of a path is cursed that you can't protect it sufficiently enough. Especially if you play solo.-very VERY little content. I went on a 4-6 month hiatus from this game and came back and there was LITERALLY NO NEW CONTENT. Just more skins. I can't believe this is acceptable for a game at any point.-There is no huntress skin where the progressive unlocks give her bigger boobs and a curvier body or the more mana she has she is curvier. (And why isn't there huh? If you're not going to put the succubus in the game at least give the huntress some more up top. Sheesh.)Look, it's free to play. Great. Should you try it? Sure why not? If you got time to spare yeah. For me I don't have time to spare. I would rather pay money for a great experience than none for a bare bones, no content experience that I don't even enjoy. If they had put it on the main page in big bold letters (THIS GAME WILL BE FREE TO PLAY AT SOME POINT) Then I would have no excuse to be upset, but money was spent on it so I am upset. Very very very little that I would want of this game came true so I am not recommending you play it or support the devs. That's it. Have a great day.TLDR - Beautiful aesthetic, good controls, great concept, way too grindy and NO CONTENT.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								No one agrees with my reviews, but I still make em. :DNov 2016 edit: And hey! Look at that slowly collapsing playerbase. Love to shove it in all the naysayers faces and told ya so. You know your game is poor when you make a free to play sequel and there are still a measurable amount playing the first. Like a third relatively speaking. BTW the game is STILL in early access...+Attractive cartoony characters and great aesthetic visual style.+Levels are pretty nice to look at and are fairly well designed.+Controls work quite well.+Abilities and towers have some synergy.+Some talents are pretty cool.+Some weapons are goofy in a good way such as 'book on a stick' that fires pages. (This fits in with the aesthetic pretty well.)+Cute pets.+Sub objectives to protect help to shape the pathing of enemies.+Stage traps that work.+Stats were made more complex.+Free to play!+Huntress is a hottie!-Glitchy/buggy. Just starting the game up and trying to switch settings around I crashed a couple times and http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/395551484001360154/C97977F6DA79498412EF112ACECC4D8C5D1E68E3/ happened which forced me to restart again. It worked after fiddling quite a bit, but it was never quite this bad.-Random framerate drops. The game used to run smoothly, but seems to struggle now for some reason even in just the lobby.-Microtransactions in early access and already priority has shifted to making more over new content: 


Yes look at all these god damn microtransaction. Look at them all! The game isn't even out of early access...Â 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders II
By: Milan Mree Frozen




-No recoloring. (This may not be big for others, but it is big for me.)-Extremely grindy.-You can only level 1 char at a time even though you can bring up to four after unlocking them all meaning you are only leveling 1 char and you will need to level them all if you want to play alone meaning MORE GRIND.-Level synching makes power leveling non existant meaning you will have to grind even more. (part of me wants to like this, but the fact you have to grind four people makes this a no no.)-Playing solo is very difficult and requires you to play even longer for any chance.-Stage traps are often inconvenient to activate, too difficult to activate, in a bad position to build walls or the timing is garbage on them.-The sub objectives in later levels don't seem to be too important especially in the ramparts where putting all your towers in a central location draws better, faster and more effecient results. They are a gimmick, one that is poorly thought out.-Playing with others is not a great experience. I know I am no saint, I am not a great person, but the community here puts my rage and general poor socialization to shame. Don't believe me, go right on ahead and try the game out.-Talents are locked behind gold walls forcing you to spend lots of gold to unlock them.-Gear and combos are too heavily emphasized. (Huntress water trap + monk aura is in almost every game.)-Minimal strategy involved. (You will set up your stuff the same almost every time simply because of the aformentioned combo and gear emphasis and magic/physical resistant enemies become pointless later on because you will NEED this setup regardless to progress.)-AI is very poor. Some enemies will get stuck, others will just not work: 


Dungeon Defenders IIÂ 
A Screenshot of Dungeon Defenders II
By: Milan Mree Frozen




  (The enemy sees my towers below and begins throwing his spear into the wall repeatedly. This is not the only time it has happened and it is easily replicatable trivializing certain encounters.)-Only four playable with four abilities (one of which is heal on everyone) and four towers means there really isn't that much variety.-Pets are a chore to level and just add more grind.-Not everyone knew this game would be F2P and not everyone is happy that it went F2P. (I wouldn't have paid a dime to play this game if I could've)-Inventory space is limited. There is an auto loot system in place where you can specify what loot goes where, but the problem is that if you have it on auto loot and you run out of space and you 'auto loot' something you want, it just goes bye bye. You can specify item rarity, but this is still a huge flaw as it CAN happen. There used to be a system in place that would take all items you left on the ground and put them in a temp chest, but for some reason they removed that (and there was no initiative vote for it.)-Initiave votes are a joke and have no real effect on the game. See: https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/11 Players have no real effect on the game with the votes. You are not changing anything or affecting anything as is evidenced by these joke of a votes. Here's another : https://dungeondefenders.com/2/initiatives/19  Oh boy choose the COLOR. So stupid. (I am pretty sure the numbers on them are skewed as well.)-Because the game is 'tower defense' it has little to no variety and the only boss in the game is just plain tedious to fight and the mechanic they do is place a 'curse' down making you have to move your towers/traps. That would be fun and such except the placement is random and it will occassionally cause your buildings to be 'cut off' from some pathing. I do not have an example unfortunately, but the idea is that so much of a path is cursed that you can't protect it sufficiently enough. Especially if you play solo.-very VERY little content. I went on a 4-6 month hiatus from this game and came back and there was LITERALLY NO NEW CONTENT. Just more skins. I can't believe this is acceptable for a game at any point.-There is no huntress skin where the progressive unlocks give her bigger boobs and a curvier body or the more mana she has she is curvier. (And why isn't there huh? If you're not going to put the succubus in the game at least give the huntress some more up top. Sheesh.)Look, it's free to play. Great. Should you try it? Sure why not? If you got time to spare yeah. For me I don't have time to spare. I would rather pay money for a great experience than none for a bare bones, no content experience that I don't even enjoy. If they had put it on the main page in big bold letters (THIS GAME WILL BE FREE TO PLAY AT SOME POINT) Then I would have no excuse to be upset, but money was spent on it so I am upset. Very very very little that I would want of this game came true so I am not recommending you play it or support the devs. That's it. Have a great day.TLDR - Beautiful aesthetic, good controls, great concept, way too grindy and NO CONTENT.

Early Access Review
								Even in Alpha, this game is amazing. It's improved greatly over the first game; the art direction is fantastic, the way battle flows is more forgiving and challenging at the same time, the division of classes is great, the pet system is fun, being able to sell items in between waves...! There are just so many different little touches that are amazing! If you like Tower Defense, there is no reason not to play Dungeon Defenders II.

content:

Early Access Review
								Not to long ago I started playing this game and before this I played "Dungeon Defenders" more than I probably should have. So far compared to the first one this is okay, but things are starting to look up as we head on into some of the higher builds of the alpha test build. I main Apprentice and I'm level 32 and I'm enjoying the game quite a bit. though the EXP much like Dungeon Defenders 1 levels 60-70 is a bit rediculous. I would say the tutorial is a bit rough (needs to be more in detail) and I also think that monks need a better set of skills. you can not possibly go 1-30 solo. it's imposible. but this is just my opinion. I've played and beat the campaign and I do hope that you will make DLC's for it to make it actually worth playing after level 23. Thanks,              Zombie

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								SCORE: 7.5/10super fun game, action packed hack and slash loot frenzy enjoyment :), great graphics with tons of details and atmosphere, great sounds and music, awesome progression and very enjoyable effects, all the stuff you want.gameplay is great, fun and hectic, in short you place defence objects and gun towers, upgrade them over time and kickâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥with your RPG kind of character. lots of fun.downsides:the game constantly have to be connected to the server, even in private mode and taverns, meaning you need to join a session just to manage your character, on top of that i did experience a few connection problems and problems leaving a game, which is kind of odd..Loot is great but there is a tad too much crap loot flooding your inventory, a "sell crap loot" button would fix this problem :), but hey we all love loot so what the heck :)Ingame purchase, yes this game does have Ingame purchase, it seems to be mostly new character slots and cosmetics etc., i did not find it an limitation doing my 3 hours play, let's hope it stay so :).all in all, this is a great game super fun with great atmosphere, if they keep from transforming it into a pay to win game, i would absolutely play it again and again :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II is a great take on the tower defense genre, placing you directly into the action in a third person view with 4 distinctive classes and a very satysfying combat system. I have never played dungeon defenders 1 but from what I am seeing with DD2 the dev team must be very commited to making a great game. The company actually gives each player "influence points" to use to vote for ideas for the dev team to make a reality in the game world. The campaign is pretty short but the replayability is pretty good, I could farm the same level for hours with the same group and still have a fun time. Discovering combos with different towers is very satysfying and rewarding in the harder stages. Comboing the monks lightning auras with the huntress' geyser traps is my personal favorite. Anyway i am rambling, but this game is definitely worth a buy and I recommend it to anyone who enjoyed DD1 or likes tower defenses.

I like to see that the game is being updated as it has a lot of potential mechanics that could be implemented.The mechanics of the game themself seem to be good.There are new Heroes to play as, which at first I was skeptical about. I do think I've grown to like the other heroes as well.In my time of playing I have encountered very few (if any) bugs! (Bugs are nasty)I definitely recommend this game, whether it be played singleplayer or played with friends.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								SCORE: 7.5/10super fun game, action packed hack and slash loot frenzy enjoyment :), great graphics with tons of details and atmosphere, great sounds and music, awesome progression and very enjoyable effects, all the stuff you want.gameplay is great, fun and hectic, in short you place defence objects and gun towers, upgrade them over time and kickâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥with your RPG kind of character. lots of fun.downsides:the game constantly have to be connected to the server, even in private mode and taverns, meaning you need to join a session just to manage your character, on top of that i did experience a few connection problems and problems leaving a game, which is kind of odd..Loot is great but there is a tad too much crap loot flooding your inventory, a "sell crap loot" button would fix this problem :), but hey we all love loot so what the heck :)Ingame purchase, yes this game does have Ingame purchase, it seems to be mostly new character slots and cosmetics etc., i did not find it an limitation doing my 3 hours play, let's hope it stay so :).all in all, this is a great game super fun with great atmosphere, if they keep from transforming it into a pay to win game, i would absolutely play it again and again :)

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								An amazing game that is full of fun, especially when you cooperate with your fellow teammates to build defenses in challenging and entertaining maps. If you are not a team-person and would prefer to get it done in your own way, the private mode is for you! With plenty of improvements from previous patches, the private mode is now more balanced. Although some would expect a tower defense game to be boring, this is far from what you would call spending tedious time to build tedious towers. With a decent variety of maps and an attractive amount of loot, this game can keep you playing on and on. This is not a pay to win game and arguably not even a pay to look good game; after a certain amount of time you can unlock many of the cosmetic items without spending a single dime! If you are into casual tower defense game, look no further.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders II is a tower defense game. It has a lot of features like items, different characters, leveling system both for characters and items, pet system, and so on. There are premium contents too like extra character slots, costumes, etc. You can play with four players at a time, and you can combine your skills to get the best setup for the map and defeat the enemies. Also, there are monthly and daily missions for rewards like pet eggs, money or items. Sometimes these missions undoable because you don't have that character or you don't have enough item power. The only disadvantage is that the game is still in development, so there are little bugs, and there are lots of updates. You can have a really good time and if you have some money I recommend you to buy extra character slots so you can easily solo almost every maps/level.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								after about 5 hours on my own, I thought this game wouldn't be as fun as the first one was if you're playing solo, so i didn't play it for about a month or 2. i just recently hopped back into this game and the changes they made were nice. a new social  "tavern" if you want which is essentialy like a small town. And i convinced a friend of mine to play this game with me and we had loads of fun, i made a new character (although my old one was about lvl 18 already) and it felt like a complete new experience when you're playing with friends. Also, playing solo isn't that boring anymore.Pros:- Very stable performance, although this is still in alpha- Fun to play with you friends- Tons of gear dropping from enemies- looks beautifully- No real P2W functions and heroes can be bought with so called hero tokens (i believe) which you get while playing- ridiculous ammount of weapons available, all with different stats- Skins look cool as hell- Free to playCons:- Not very fun to play in solo, but much more than before- quite a few bugs- collecting these hero tokens can take quite a whileOverall, I'll give this game a solid 8.5/10And since i know tendy they'll include much more content to the game later on and fix all bugsFor me, personally, it's at least as fun as the first one is.The only thing I'm waiting for now are the Turkey Hunts :D

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like Tower Defense and FPSes, DD2 is a great game for you.  It is very different from DD1 and sure, there's a lot of people out there feeling that the gear curve is very linear in nature and there are only certain builds that matter - but the game itself remains a very fun game to play.Trendy continues to release regular improvements to the game - new maps, new heroes, bug fixes - and for the few glitches that remain, the game itself is highly enjoyable.Level up your characters to 50 and then the game really starts as you try to defeat the hardest difficulties to get the best gear in the game.  The social elements of the game still need a pretty solid bump in a better direction - most of the community seems a bit cold and stand-offish - but if you can make a few friends, the game gets a bit crazy, a lot more fun and actually even easier to win alongside other players! :)

It was fine for me but after a while they put the new characters on sale over the game-money and the 3000 some kind of moey they give us would only be enought to buy only 2 characters which is totally unacceptable... Im writing this to show the bad evaluation of the game since the first df and the reason im writing this to here is to show how bad this game has beome and why you shouldnt buy it !!Have a good day...

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This GAME is amazing tho on early access and Alpha stage. The graphic's for the game are mind blowing for a Alpha Stratergy Rpg game. You have 4 characters to choose from Squire, Archer, Apprentice and The Monk. They all have their own unique Skills + Traps. I mean yes there are alot of Negative review's and I can understand why but I find that this is one of the best Alpha stage RPG game that existed (well that is what I see). The game has many levels in it, and the difficulty get's harder everytime you get a new enemy/boss/flying enemies/Etc so yea you wont get bored of it anytime soon. I hope this review helps some people who are looking for a good fairly cheap RPG game. Hope this will help.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I loved the original DD so it was a no brainer to spend some dough to support the team making DD2. The game looks good, the same colorful quality that was so enjoyable about the first game. Collecting gear, raising pets and hacking and slashing your way through hoards of rather cute goblins and ogres? Yep, got that too.  It's still in pre-alpha so there's a lot of game rebalancing and renovating going on pretty frequently.What it is missing for me is that feeling I got in DD where I put up a few traps or towers in just the right spots and I become god of the level. They haven't fine tuned it to that level yet but I'm hopeful. All in all, it is a true successor to the original and worth a play.

Early Access Review
								(Alpha Review) It's fun and average battle length is 10-20 mins meaning you can do a quick one or a marathon.  Loot is starting be show diversity and progression is coming along.  Battles are very easy right now, maybe too easy but there are harder difficulties.There is no Pay to Win to be seen.For the future, I hope they increase the difficulty somewhat and avoid the power creep Dungeon Defenders 1 had by making Nightmare battles simply have the same loot drops as Insane but with increased rarity chance. As a note, still concerned with the pricing of the costumes however they have gotten a bit cooler and the price means that you're more likely to have a Unique look.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Game is fun, so at a minimum it has that going for it. Standard loot grind keeps you invested in gearing up your characters. Varied enough feeling maps, but leveling up is very restricted to only a few worthwhile choices. The tower defense part is the more fun and interesting aspect for me personally, sometimes I just want to be able to sit back and let my towers do the work - you can't really do this if you're trying to actively gear up at the same time. So anyone looking for ONLY tower defense might not like it that much. As I said before, it's a fun game if you like the genre(s) and gear treadmill gameplay.And about the DLC. It's not as bad as some people make it out to be. First, for anyone who was totaling up the amount or cost - you absolutely do not need to buy every one to enjoy the game. You really don't need to buy any for that matter. I've gotten 3 of the cheapest options so far - 1 was a purely cosmetic costume pack on sale - and don't regret supporting the devs who are transparently working on the game, and I also feel like if I hadn't bought any I'd be at the same level of enjoyment. That seems like DLC done well to me.Just a warning though, I would strongly recommend holding off on the Inventory pack - they have changed up loot drops quite a bit and recently you get MUCH LESS LOOT (not a complaint because the overall quality of each piece is better), MAKING INVENTORY SPACE LESS NEEDED OVERALL. It's the only purchase I regret from this game, although it did get me extra 2 hero slots to use whenever I want, plus some gems. But hero slots are also something I would not recommend at all until you've already leveled 4 characters completely

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Have you ever wanted a game where the community isn't entirely d1cks or a game where you can do what you please as long as you have a full lobby? Then look no further because Dungeon Defenders 2 has it all! Strategic boss fights when you are actually a lower level than the boss (being under level for any fight is fun as hell), lot's of difficulty selections (Freeplay with easy, normal, and hard then there's Endgame with hard, insane, Nightmare 1 - Nightmare 4) each difficulty has their perks. The harder the level the better the loot. The Devs take care of bugs when you tell them about it which is useful as all hell, and as I said before the community isn't full of total d0uche bags. Play this game you won't regret it!
